title: Painting Produce - 6 Week Watercolor Course
description:
In this 6 week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium. The class will focus on strengthening one’s observational skills, giving the artist a foundation off of which to build their paintings in a step by step layering process, that trains the artist to see value and color

Our unifying subject will be seasonal produce - fruits, veggies and herbs. These subjects are great for beginners and experienced watercolor painters alike; their organic shapes make them forgiving drawing subjects, but their beauty can be a muse for life. 

This class will work from life, practicing basic drawing skills in addition to watercolor technique. With six class sessions, participants will have the opportunity to develop their skills and build muscle memory with a medium that often feels like it has a mind of its own. All skill levels welcome and all materials included.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Mushrooms: Wonders of the Woods!
description:
Join an interactive hour of hands-on fun exploring the fascinating world of mushrooms! Learn how to identify mushrooms, discover yummy edibles like chanterelles, morels, and porcini, and understand the difference between edible and poisonous varieties. We will have some specimens to touch and smell. Fork in the Path offers forest-to-table learning programs for the adventurous of all ages across Northern California. Programming includes mushroom and plant foraging, tasting wild food, cultivating a respectful and reciprocal relationship with the land, making art, and community building.

title: Homeopathy: Practical Remedies for Healing with Annie Osborn L.Ac.
description:
Homeopathy: Practical Remedies for Healing is an educational and empowering talk that brings the gentle yet powerful principles of homeopathy into everyday life.

 Drawing from the same global wisdom highlighted in the film Introducing Homeopathy—that healing can be effective, subtle, and deeply respectful of the body’s innate intelligence—this presentation explores the foundations of homeopathy, its history, and how potencies work.

Annie Osborn will demystify this often-misunderstood modality and ground it in practical, real-world applications that support the whole person: body, mind, and nervous system.

With over 25 years in natural medicine, Annie shares clinical pearls rarely taught, offering guidance on remedies for common ailments such as pain, allergies, digestion, insomnia, hormonal balance, mood challenges, and first aid, along with powerful approaches to detoxification and deeper healing support for issues like nerve health and bone strength. Her insights echo the film’s message that homeopathy is not just a theory, but a living, time-tested system used worldwide—one that invites curiosity, personal empowerment, and a more conscious relationship with health and healing.

Be sure to attend the viewing of Introducing Homeopathy with us in the EESystem on February 7th!

ABOUT ANNIE OSBORN

Annie Osborn is a natural medicine kinesiologist and licensed acupuncturist for 25 years in Sonoma County.  She was the technical specialist for 12 years at Boericke & Tafel Homeopathic Company, where she trained health store staff in homeopathy. There she attended 35 homeopathic conferences.  Annie has a certificate in homeopathic principles and practice, and has been using homeopathy in her practice for over 30 years.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Thornton Wilder's The Skin of Our Teeth
description:
The Skin of Our Teeth is Thornton Wilder’s bold, three-part allegory of human survival. It follows the Antrobus family through ages of natural disaster, war, and renewal. Blending surrealist comedy with epic drama, the play captures humanity’s continual struggle to endure “by the skin of our teeth”—an urgent message in today’s world of conflict and climate crisis.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Hands on a Hardbody
location: Spreckels Center for the Performing Arts
description:
In this quirky, high-stakes musical based on real events, ten Texans compete to keep one hand on a brand-new truck the longest—and the last one standing wins it. But this is more than just a contest; it’s a hilarious, heartfelt look at resilience, community and what drives us. This soulful, country-rock musical is filled with a moving score and unforgettable characters. Hands on a Hardbody is a ride you’ll want to take!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Literary Event: Red Flag Warning
description:
Sunday February 15 th . 2-4PM. Occidental Center for the Arts Literary Series hosts

the writers of Red Flag Warning: Mutual Aid and Survival in California's Fire

Country: edited by Dani Burlison & Margaret Elysia Garcia. (AK Press) A guide for

living physically, mentally and emotionally amid ecological destruction. Readers are

invited to examine what fire can and does mean to them and what it means for us to re-

imagine the world. Presenters from this collection include Dani Burlison, Manjula Martin,

Hiya Swanhuyser Beatrice Camacho, and  Amy Elizabeth Robinson.

Free admission, all donations gratefully accepted. Selected readings, and conversation

with the audience, followed by book sales and signing. Refreshments for sale. OCA:

title: Mary Poppins
description:
**The magical, family-friendly musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film.**

***“It’s a roof-raising, toe-tapping, high-flying extravaganza.“* — Joe Dziemianowicz, New York Daily News** 

**The beloved story of *Mary Poppins* soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.**

**Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” this spectacular production will leave audiences of all ages believing that anything is possible—especially with a little magic in the air!**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: Two hours, 50 mins including intermission

title: Literary Event: Red Flag Warning
description:
Occidental Center for the Arts Literary Series hosts the writers of Red Flag Warning: Mutual Aid and Survival in California's Fire Country: edited by Dani Burlison & Margaret Elysia Garcia. \(AK Press\) A guide for living physically, mentally and emotionally amid ecological destruction. Readers are invited to examine what fire can and does mean to them and what it means for us to re-imagine the world. Presenters from this collection include Dani Burlison, Manjula Martin, Hiya Swanhuyser Beatrice Camacho, and Amy Elizabeth Robinson. Free admission, all donations gratefully accepted. Selected readings, and conversation with the audience, followed by book sales and signing. Refreshments for sale. OCA's facilities are accessible to people with disabilities.   Dani Burlison \(she/her\) is a writer and teacher from rural Northern California. Her books include "Red Flag Warning: Mutual Aid and Survival in California's Fire Country" \(co-editor, AK Press, 2025\), "Some Places Worth Leaving" \(Tolsun Books, 2020\), and "All of Me: Love, Anger and the Female Body" \(PM Press, 2019\). She makes zines, is a co-founder of the  CAW anarchist collective, and has been a staff writer at a Bay Area Alt-weekly and a columnist at McSweeney's Internet Tendency. Dani's writing can also be found in Ms. Magazine, Yes! Magazine,  KQED Arts, The Rumpus, Earth Island Journal, Portland Review and elsewhere. She teaches at SRJC and is a single mom of two young adults.  Manjula Martin is author of The Last Fire Season: A Personal and Pyronatural History. She is coauthor of Fruit Trees for Every Garden, which won the 2020 American Horticultural Society Book Award. Martin edited the anthology Scratch: Writers, Money, and the Art of Making a Living, and she was managing editor of the National Magazine Award-winning literary journal Zoetrope: All-Story. She lives in western Sonoma County, California.   Hiya Swanhuyser is a a writer from Northern California. She is a founding member of Substrate Arts, a co-operative online magazine covering Bay Area creative scenes. Her writing has appeared in the Press Democrat, the North Bay Bohemian, KQED Arts, Mission Local, the Believer, Fandor's Keyframe, and others. She is writing a book about the Montgomery Block, a little-known Bohemian mecca that once stood where the Transamerica Pyramid is now. She grew up on a semi-communal family farm in Occidental.   Beatrice Camacho is the UndocuFund Director and a Community Organizer. She is a first-generation Chicana raised in Sonoma County to low-income, working-class parents who immigrated from Northern Mexico. As a lifelong renter, growing up on Section 8 Housing, she knows the importance of dignified and affordable housing. She is trained in Restorative Justice and Restorative Practices. An organizer with the North Bay Organizing Project since 2018, she organized the Sonoma County Tenants Union, organizes community pop-up healing clinics, and co-founded the statewide California UndocuFund Network.  Amy Elizabeth Robinson lived in the eastern mountains of Sonoma County, California, until her family's home and community were lost to wildfire. She is a poet, writer, reader, historian, and many other things; she studies Zen and the creative process with Rachel Boughton, Roshi at  Flower Mountain Zen , and is on the Steering Committee for the North Bay chapter of the Working Famil

title: Mushrooms: Wonders of the Woods!
description:
Join an interactive hour of hands-on fun exploring the fascinating world of mushrooms! Learn how to identify mushrooms, discover yummy edibles like chanterelles, morels, and porcini, and understand the difference between edible and poisonous varieties. We will have some specimens to touch and smell. Fork in the Path offers forest-to-table learning programs for the adventurous of all ages across Northern California. Programming includes mushroom and plant foraging, tasting wild food, cultivating a respectful and reciprocal relationship with the land, making art, and community building.

title: Homeopathy: Practical Remedies for Healing with Annie Osborn L.Ac.
description:
**Homeopathy: Practical Remedies for Healing** is an educational and empowering talk that brings the gentle yet powerful principles of homeopathy into everyday life.

 Drawing from the same global wisdom highlighted in the film ***Introducing Homeopathy***—that healing can be effective, subtle, and deeply respectful of the body’s innate intelligence—this presentation explores the foundations of homeopathy, its history, and how potencies work.

**Annie Osborn will demystify this often-misunderstood modality and ground it in practical, real-world applications that support the whole person: body, mind, and nervous system.**

With over 25 years in natural medicine, Annie shares clinical pearls rarely taught, offering guidance on remedies for common ailments such as pain, allergies, digestion, insomnia, hormonal balance, mood challenges, and first aid, along with powerful approaches to detoxification and deeper healing support for issues like nerve health and bone strength. Her insights echo the film’s message that homeopathy is not just a theory, but a living, time-tested system used worldwide—one that invites curiosity, personal empowerment, and a more conscious relationship with health and healing.

**Be sure to attend the viewing of Introducing Homeopathy with us in the EESystem on February 7th!**

**ABOUT ANNIE OSBORN**

Annie Osborn is a natural medicine kinesiologist and licensed acupuncturist for 25 years in Sonoma County.  She was the technical specialist for 12 years at Boericke & Tafel Homeopathic Company, where she trained health store staff in homeopathy. There she attended 35 homeopathic conferences.  Annie has a certificate in homeopathic principles and practice, and has been using homeopathy in her practice for over 30 years.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Hands on a Hardbody
location: Spreckels Center for the Performing Arts
description:
In this quirky, high-stakes musical based on real events, ten Texans compete to keep one hand on a brand-new truck the longest—and the last one standing wins it. But this is more than just a contest; it’s a hilarious, heartfelt look at resilience, community and what drives us. This soulful, country-rock musical is filled with a moving score and unforgettable characters. *Hands on a Hardbody* is a ride you’ll want to take!

Source: Press Democrat

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

title: Stay With Us - On The House
description:
Now through February 22, The Lodge at Dawn Ranch is inviting guests to linger longer and make a staycation out of dinner, offering complimentary accommodations at the 22-acre creative retreat Dawn Ranch.

The 1-night hotel stay is gifted to those who reserve the ‘All That’ tasting menu for two, alongside the ‘The Timeless Wine Pairing,’ carefully crafted by award-winning Advanced Sommelier Genaro Gallo. The 12-course journey takes guests through a series of small bites, composed dishes and mains, a pre-dessert, and a final dessert - each paired with a glass of wine representing a different decade, from the 1970s to today. A few signature dishes featured this season include:

A Thousand-Layer Potato and Caviar

Three Corn Polenta with Black Truffle and Egg Yolk

Sea Urchin Bucatini; and Dates with Tonka Bean Ice Cream and Orange Bourbon Glaze

Following dinner, diners will be treated to a stay in one of Dawn Ranch’s 86 cottages and cabins. Reservations for the “Stay With Us – On The House” promotion can be made through OpenTable for Sunday or Monday evenings, for bookings through February 22.

**Mercy’s Bingo Smokeout at The Lounge at Mercy**

Join us for Mercy’s Bingo Smokeout, a laid-back, elevated bingo night at **The Lounge at Mercy**. Come kick back, light up, and play a few rounds of bingo in a cozy, social setting designed for good vibes and great company. Whether you’re a bingo pro or just in it for the smoke and the laughs, this is your new favorite Sunday ritual.

**When:** 1st & 3rd Sundays of every month

**Where:** The Lounge at Mercy

**Age Requirement:** 21+ only

**Licensed Venue:** DCC # C12-0000420-LIC

Expect relaxed energy, friendly competition, and a community atmosphere that feels like home. Grab your seat, bring your lucky charm, and let’s play.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Free pipe organ concert Feb. 15 in Healdsburg
description:
John Karl Hirten, the director of music at St. John's Episcopal Church in the Marin County city of Ross, plays a concert of Bach, Bruhns, Milhaud, Hewitt and his own composition in Healdsburg on Sunday, Feb. 15. Admission to the 5 p.m. concert is free and takes place at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, located at the corner of East and Matheson Streets, one block east of Healdsburg's downtown Plaza.

Source: Press Democrat

title: “Stay With Us – On The House” at The Lodge at Dawn Ranch
description:
Now through February 22, **The Lodge at Dawn Ranch** is inviting guests to linger longer and make a staycation out of dinner, offering **complimentary accommodations at the 22-acre creative retreat Dawn Ranch.**

The 1-night hotel stay is gifted to those who reserve th**e ‘*All That*’ tasting menu for two, alongside the ‘*The Timeless Wine Pairin*g,’** carefully crafted by award-winning Advanced Sommelier Genaro Gallo. The 12-course journey takes guests through a series of small bites, composed dishes and mains, a pre-dessert, and a final dessert - each paired with a glass of wine representing a different decade, from the 1970s to today. A few signature dishes featured this season include:

A **Thousand-Layer Potato** and Caviar

**Three Corn Polenta** with Black Truffle and Egg Yolk

**Sea Urchin Bucatini**; and **Dates with Tonka Bean Ice Cream** and Orange Bourbon Glaze

Following dinner, **diners will be treated to a stay in one of Dawn Ranch’s 86 cottages and cabins.** Reservations for the “Stay With Us – On The House” promotion can be made through OpenTable for Sunday or Monday evenings, for bookings through February 22.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Flamenco Audaz
description:
The ancient art form of Flamenco serves as a symbol of unity among diverse communities and is recognized internationally as an essential part of Spain's heritage. It embodies the spirit of the Spanish people, capturing a wide range of emotions such as joy, sorrow, and defiance, more relevant than ever in today’s world. Flamenco's recognition by UNESCO as an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity in 2010 further underscores its cultural significance.

At its core, flamenco is an intensely emotional art form. The performances, characterized by passionate singing \(cante\), intricate guitar playing \(toque\), and expressive dance \(baile\), convey feelings that are often difficult to articulate. The concept of "duende," refers to the soulful connection between performer and audience, representing authenticity and emotional depth. Flamenco allows artists to express their personal experiences and connect with the audience on a visceral level, making each performance unique.

'polyglottistlanguageacademy.com'

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Fortepianist Daniel Adam Maltz
description:
**Classical music as it was intended to be heard: on a Viennese fortepiano.**

In this delightful concert, Vienna-based fortepianist Daniel Adam Maltz and soprano Jennifer Ellis Kampani perform Mozart, Haydn, and Beethoven as those composers intended their music to be heard.

Daniel specializes in historically informed performance. Called “the foremost performer in the world of the fortepiano” (Aspen Daily News), he has been praised for imbuing “\[Beethoven’s\] tenderness, longing, and frustration into the very notes” (Orlando Sentinel), for “lavish but tasteful” playing (Classical Sonoma), and as “a privilege to hear” (Marblehead Current). He studied at the Royal Academy of Music in London and at the University for Music and Performing Arts in Vienna and performs exclusively on historic Viennese fortepianos.

Appearing with him at the Raven is Grammy-nominated soprano Jennifer Ellis Kampani, who is known for her expressive interpretations of Lieder — Classical-era songs. Ellis Kampari has appeared at Carnegie Hall and performed with leading ensembles including American Bach Soloists, Apollo’s Fire, Opera Lafayette, and Portland Baroque Orchestra. She lives in Los Angeles and teaches at USC. Sunday, February 15th. 7:00 PM. Front of House: $38 General Admission: $23 Student: $13

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description:

Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Family Hike at Sugarloaf
description:
Come to the park for a peaceful hike through the woods on Monday, February 16! Join our Docents on this fun family hike that is good for all ages, where you will learn about Sugarloaf Park, its plants, animals, and history. 

The hike begins from the Visitor Center. One option heads down to the waterfall on the Pony Gate-Canyon loop, while a second option will meander along the Creekside Nature Trail. Please note the route is bound to change depending on logistics such as wet crossings and the participants' physical ability. Free event, RSVP required. Wear layers, appropriate footwear for slippery/muddy trails, bring at least a quart (32oz) of water, sun protection, and if desired, a snack. Heavy rains cancel. Parking fees apply.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: S.T.E.A.M Room
description:
Visit our S.T.E.A.M. Room, in the Dow Event Center adjacent to Ella’s Art Studio, open every Sunday and Monday from 10:00am – 3:00pm. Children and families can explore activities and materials at their own pace. A Playologist will facilitate accompanying programming from 1:00-3:00pm.  

S.T.E.A.M stands for Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math. The provided activities and materials engage children in these principles and concepts and rotate monthly.

title: Shut Up & Write!® at Aqus in Petaluma (in person)
description:
Shut Up & Write!® Wine Country
**Coworking for writers in Petaluma!**
Join us for some focused writing time. All experience levels are welcome, and don’t worry, no one will see what you've written. This session is about getting some writing done, whether you're working on a novel, memoir, short story, dissertation, job application, blog, poetry, a song or just want to journal.

**Format**
10:30 - 10:45am: Introduce yourself and what you're working on today
10:45 - 11:45am: Write in silence for 1 hour
11:45am - 12pm: Check in with one another and exchange how it went

**Venue Details:**

* Aqus has WiFi for guests
* Ample street parking is available
* Please thank our hosts by purchasing something
* If music or ambient noise are distracting, please bring ear plugs or headphones
* There are a few outlets available if you need to charge your device

Source: Meetup: Shut Up & Write Wine Country
source: Meetup: Shut Up & Write Wine Country

title: Join Our Podcast!
description:
Share your story on Sonoma County Library's Impromptu Podcast! The rules are simple: You will have 30 seconds to read the prompt and then we start recording your story. Tell us your name \(if you want\). Use the prompt in the story. Keep it PG. You have 3 minutes to share your story. When we gather 4 or 5 stories, we will share the podcast on Sonoma County Library's YouTube channel and cable access channel!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney’s Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

Source: North Bay Bohemian

description:

Offered Monday through Wednesday from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM, this experience invites guests to enjoy a curated flight of only 3 pours total at our tasting bar, featuring wines that highlight our Russian River Valley roots and single-vineyard focus.

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:
**WHAT:** Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         **Offered Daily:** 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

·         **Experience length:** 2 hours

·         **Wines:** Selections of library, limited single-vineyard, and a barrel tasting of yet-to-be-released Cabernet Sauvignon

·         **Cost:** $150 per Person

·         **Exclusive Member Price:** $95 per Member

**ADMISSION:** Members $95 | Non-members $150

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Picnic Lunch and Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
Begin your wine-tasting experience with a guided tasting led by our host, who will introduce you to our exclusive estate Russian River Valley wines. Once you have found your favorite, choose a glass from our specialty curated wine flight to enjoy with a delicious picnic lunch, prepared by our local partners at Willow Wood Market & Cafe. Reservations required with advanced booking of 48 hours.

$85 per guest | Club Member: $45 per guest

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
A relaxed and elegant garden experience! Your host will guide you through a tasting of our Russian River Valley estate wines. In inclement weather, this experience will be hosted in our charming tasting room.

Enhance your visit with an option to add-on cheese & charcuterie or artisanal chocolates to make your wine country experience even more delightful.

$40 per guest | Refundable with two bottle purchase

Club Member: Four Complimentary Tastings per Visit

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Nature Explorers
description:
Nature Explorers helps families explore the art and science of the natural world. 

Join us with an experienced California Naturalist through a variety of programs with hands-on experiences from specimen exploration to “creature features” and nature hunts.  

This program is held out and about in Mary’s Garden after storytime at 10:30am. 

All ages welcome!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Arts Guild of Sonoma Presents: For the Love of Art
description:
For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma. The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. Learn more at  artsguildofsonoma.org .

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Sparkling Valentine’s Tasting at Cuvaison
description:
Celebrate Valentine’s season with a sparkling experience surrounded by the beauty of the Tai vineyard, where rolling vineyards and tranquil scenery set the mood.

Guests will enjoy a curated flight featuring elegant sparkling wine alongside expressive estate selections, perfect for savoring together. The experience invites you to slow down, toast to February, and indulge in the beauty of wine country.

**Group Size**:

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.

Sonoma County artists, Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich present the Color of Love, paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features Laura Roney’s Dance!, a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. \(707\) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    www.upstairsart gallery.net

Source: Press Democrat

title: Stay With Us - On The House
description:
Now through February 22, The Lodge at Dawn Ranch is inviting guests to linger longer and make a staycation out of dinner, offering complimentary accommodations at the 22-acre creative retreat Dawn Ranch.

The 1-night hotel stay is gifted to those who reserve the ‘All That’ tasting menu for two, alongside the ‘The Timeless Wine Pairing,’ carefully crafted by award-winning Advanced Sommelier Genaro Gallo. The 12-course journey takes guests through a series of small bites, composed dishes and mains, a pre-dessert, and a final dessert - each paired with a glass of wine representing a different decade, from the 1970s to today. A few signature dishes featured this season include:

A Thousand-Layer Potato and Caviar

Three Corn Polenta with Black Truffle and Egg Yolk

Sea Urchin Bucatini; and Dates with Tonka Bean Ice Cream and Orange Bourbon Glaze

Following dinner, diners will be treated to a stay in one of Dawn Ranch’s 86 cottages and cabins. Reservations for the “Stay With Us – On The House” promotion can be made through OpenTable for Sunday or Monday evenings, for bookings through February 22.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Yoga with Carem - Restore, Rejuvenate, Reconnect
description:
Unwind, restore, and reconnect with your mind and body. Designed for all levels, each session focuses on gentle yet purposeful poses, mindful breathing, and deep relaxation to help you release the stress of the day.

Whether you’re looking to improve flexibility, build strength, calm your nervous system, or simply create space for self-care, this class offers a supportive environment to nurture both body and mind. End your day feeling centered, refreshed, and rejuvenated.

What to Expect:

Gentle, mindful sequencing suitable for all levels

Focus on alignment, posture, and breath awareness

Deep stretches and calming poses to promote relaxation

Optional modifications to meet your individual needs

Bring a mat, water, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

About Carem

Carem Love is a wellness advocate, professional dancer, and certified yoga instructor with a Bachelor’s degree in Dance. She has extensive training in Bellydance, a deep passion for Latin dance, and is certified in Hatha, Vinyasa, and Children’s Yoga.

Yoga has profoundly supported her health, well-being, and dance career, inspiring her to help others experience the same body-mind benefits. In her classes, students strengthen their bodies, improve posture, mobility, balance and flexibility and learn to connect more deeply with themselves.

What to bring:  mat, water, yoga blocks if you need them, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: Press Democrat

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney’s Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

Source: North Bay Bohemian

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Intro to Tap for Adults
description:
Welcome to the wonderful world of Tap! This class offering is for 6 weeks, Tuesdays from 11 am-12 pm, starting February 17th. This open level class is for those who wish to discover tap dance and those who wish to continue exploring. Classes will be led by Starr Hergenrather, Mindy Copeland and Gabe Copeland. A limited supply of tap shoes is available for use at the class.  Please contact us ahead of time to ensure we have the right size for you.  Participation fee is $150 for the session, $125 for OCA members.  Register  Tap Dance provides an avenue for developing coordination, balance, musicality, rhythm, and general love for movement. We will learn the basics \(if a beginner\) and beyond, through warm-ups, discover the language of tap dance, learn the Shim Sham, and routines that will launch you onto your own exploration of the dance form. Tap is an extremely fun and rewarding form of dance. Tap Dance originated in the 19th century through a fusion of African and Irish dance styles, becoming a unique American art form in the melting pot of New York City. It developed through percussive footwork, initially on plantations and in urban cellars, and later gained widespread popularity through minstrel shows, vaudeville, and Hollywood musicals. Innovators like  Bill "Bojangles" Robinson , the  Nicholas Brothers , Eleanor Powell, Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly to name just a few, who shaped its evolution, which continues today with new fusions in contemporary dance. May 26, Bojangle's birthday, is National Tap Dance Day. Starr Hergenrather has been teaching Theatre and Dance for over 54 years, dancing for 70 years, which is amazing since she is only 45 years old! She received her Theatre Arts and Teaching Credentials in 1971 from Denver, CO. Starr has taught theatre/creative dramatics/improvisation/dance to all ages and directed and produced theatre for many, many years. She and her family moved to Sebastopol in 1983. In 1987, she received her Dance credential and degree from SSU. Starr loves the theatre and dance and everything about them. She has performed on stage and in film throughout her teaching career. Before joining the staff at Analy in 2001 where she became the Theatre Arts Program Director and taught one dance class starting in 2010, when the high school lost its Dance instructor due to No Child Left Behind, she taught at Brookhaven School from 1990-2001 teaching a myriad of subjects, including Theatre and Dance, and Rincon Valley Junior High School from 1987-1997, as BJ Van Noy's choreographer and asst. director of her Music Program. Starr's tap mentor was a Vaudeville and later Broadway song and Dance man by the name of Jack Williams. Starr studied with Jack for almost 20 years., until his waning years. Tap, which is a magical form of dance, btw, is Starr's first dance love, next to swing, salsa, and partner dancing, and then just plain social, wild hippie dancing at concerts. Starr also teaches Private Tap Lessons for any level dancer. Starr has a studio at her home.

description:
Discover your family story at our Family Search Center You will find our center in the Lakeport building in the room next to the nursery. Local volunteers can help jumpstart your family history journey. Our center is staffed on Tuesdays from 1pm - 4pm, reach us in person or by phone \(707\) 280-9545 during those hours. All services provided in centers are free. You’ll enjoy: Personalized help Center guests can receive personal help from volunteers in one of more than 5,400 centers worldwide. Access to technology Centers offer complimentary access to computers, internet, and subscription family history websites. Available resources vary by location. Access to exclusive records Visitors to FamilySearch Centers get special access to images of historical records that are only available in centers. Websites available at all locations: Ancestry, My Heritage, Family Search, Find My Past, American Ancestors, Geneanet https://www.family search.org Explore videos about family history and temples at collection/temple-and-family-history-messages-from-leaders?lang=eng

In this class is about making sure you can do what you want to do, for as long as you want to do it. It’s about creating that strong foundation for a truly active lifestyle. Dance, Exercise, and Staying Fit.

low impact

building muscles

movement

confidence

title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM – 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 – Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you’ll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist:  Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\), Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\) . Inspired by their playful styles, students will design and develop their very own characters—deciding where these characters live, work, play, eat, and sleep! Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.  Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

 watercolor, paint, pens, and collage

 recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use watercolor techniques to add color and mood

How scale helps characters and environments feel real

The arc of a story—beginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 116

title: After-School Adventure Gaming
description:
Tuesdays, February 10 – April 7, 2026 4:00 PM – 6:00 PM Exception: No class March 24

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Teens

Age\(s\)

10-15

$360 – Registration CostPresented by the Sonoma Community Center in partnership with The Game Academy

Join Adventure Gaming classes with The Game Academy! Play D&D, build community, and grow empathy through weekly storytelling sessions.

About the class

class descriptionAdventure Gaming classes presented by The Game Academy are held weekly for 2-hour sessions over an 8-week term. Participating players explore collaborative storytelling in a mentorship model using games like Dungeons & Dragons to build community, foster empathy, and support social-emotional growth. Our trained Educator-Gamemasters guide players in choosing the kinds of stories that interest them, then support unique and dynamic character creation, and finally present an engaging narrative filled with puzzles and mysteries to be solved, social role-play to navigate, and tactical challenges to be overcome… all based on the players’ interests. This uniquely tailored experience provides a rich context of personal investment, and engages our players with a fun and collaborative activity that helps them overcome social and emotional challenges, teaches them to engage with a growth mindset, supports the development of critical thinking and cooperative problem-solving skills, and helps them form lasting bonds with their peers. We hope your child will join us for a new adventure this coming Fall Term at the Sonoma Community Center.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Location

Room 211, Conference Room

title: Wise Girl Workshops - School Year Wellness Workshops
description:
Whose ready to be a part of an amazing group of girls and youth who are open minded and hearted—ready to make new friends AND develop essential life skills to help them learn to live well?

We are now enrolling for our School Year Wellness Workshops for girls in 3rd-8th grades.

Meeting for a full 15 weeks, members make fantastic friendships, have fun engaging in activities and art projects, and learn social-emotional-physical tools that will help them throughout their lifetime.

We’ve got 3 amazing facilitators and workshops are hosted at McKinley School in Petaluma-though members come from a variety of schools and towns to attend opening up even further opportunities for making even more friends!

\*Grades 3/4 meets on Wednesday's from Jan 14-May 13

\*Grades 5/6 meets on Tuesday's Jan 13-May 12

\*Additional Grades 5/6 meets on Wednesdays from Jan 14-May 13

\*Grades 7/8 meets on Thursday's from Jan 15-May 14

Ready to learn more and register?

wisegirlworkshops.com/workshops-and-services/school-year-wellness-workshop-series/

Here’s to growing Wise Girls and Youth!

title: Mardi Paws 2026
description:
Laissez les bons temps rouler!

Let the good times roll at our 2026 Mardi Paws Celebration, a joyful evening benefiting the Humane Society of the North Bay!

Step into the magic of Mardi Gras and join us for a lively evening inspired by the heart and soul of New Orleans—all in support of a cause that saves lives.

Enjoy a mouthwatering Cajun-style buffet by award-winning Vallejo favorite Provisions, with delicious vegetarian options available. Mingle and toast the night at Provisions’ French Quarter–style bar as you reconnect with old friends and make new ones. Doors open at 5:30 PM for appetizers and a no-host bar to kick off the celebration.

After dinner, let the fun continue with our high-energy Dessert Dash, where sweet treats and friendly competition collide. Take a chance on exciting raffle prizes, and don’t miss your opportunity to add to the festive flair with Mardi Gras beads, masks, and light-up accessories available for purchase.

Every ticket, raffle entry, and donation directly supports the lifesaving care of homeless dogs and cats as they wait for their forever homes. Your generosity turns a night of celebration into a second chance for animals in need.

So bring your friends, your Mardi Gras spirit, and your checkbook, credit card, or cash—and let the good times roll for a cause that truly matters.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Beginner Salsa - Tuesdays
description:
Ready to dance? Join our beginner salsa class where no experience or partner is needed. Just comfortable shoes and desire to have fun!

Great for first timers!

No dance experience required

Non-marking shoes soles

No partner necessary

Our relaxed environment is perfect for learning salsa basics, as we make it fun and enjoyable. In this class you will learn basic directional steps, proper frame for partner-work and simple turn patterns. We organize our curriculum so that the movements are easy to remember. Join us to learn the fundamentals! No experience is necessary and no partner is required. Drop-in fee is $20.

Date & Time: Tuesdays @ 5:30PM – 6:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: 35th MardiGras Mambofest! Rhythmtown-Jive - Big Petaluma Tradition lives on
description:
Announcing the 35th Annual Mardi Gras Mambofest! The Big Annual Tradition lives on in downtown Petaluma — and it’s time to dance.

Join us Fat Tuesday, February 17 at the Mystic Theatre for an electrifying Fat Tuesday Dance Concert \+ street parade, featuring an all-star lineup of Rhythmtown-Jive favorites and special guests.

 Featuring musicians from Rhythmtown-Jive: Snakebite Jacobs • Kevin Zuffi • Tim Eschliman • Rene Jenkins

 Plus special guests: Johnny Bones & Beau Beaullieu \(The California Honeydrops\) Keta Bill • Katie Guthorn • Kathy Kennedy \(Big Bang Beat\)

 FAT TUESDAY STREET PARADE We’ll kick things off with a festive Brass & Rhythm Band parade at 6:15 PM, starting in front of the Mystic Theatre and rolling through downtown Petaluma \(weather permitting\). Deck out, get loud, and follow the groove!

 These incredible players have performed with legends including Etta James, Commander Cody, Joe Louis Walker, Natalie Cole, Mary Wilson, Smokey Robinson, and many more.

 Beads encouraged. Costumes celebrated. Dancing mandatory.

 NOTE: We strongly recommend purchasing tickets in advance — this annual tradition sells out!

title: Year Of The Horse: Chinese New Year Sound Healing Journey
description:
Celebrate the Chinese New Year with Sound, Intention & Renewal with Chris Young-Ginzburg and Heather Star

Step into a sanctuary of sound, song, and energy as we welcome the Chinese New Year, a powerful threshold of renewal, rebirth, and fresh beginnings.

In Chinese cosmology, the New Year is a time to clear old energy, honor what has been, and consciously call in new blessings, vitality, and aligned direction for the year ahead. This celebration welcomes the Year of the Horse, an archetype of movement, heart-led momentum, freedom, and life force \(Qi\)-inviting us to release stagnation and move forward in truth and alignment. Join Chris Young-Ginzburg and Heather Star for a deeply nourishing Chinese New Year Sound Healing Journey at the Energy Wave Center. Through channeled songs, crystal sound bowls, and intuitive vocal harmonies, you’ll be bathed in frequencies designed to: • Release stagnant energy from the past year • Soothe the nervous system and quiet the mind • Open the heart to clarity, joy, and intention • Align your body and spirit with the rhythms of renewal The voices of Heather and Chris are often described as angelic, sending ripples of love and healing through the space. Their harmonies invite deep emotional release, remembrance, and soul-level realignment-supporting the forward-moving, heart-centered energy of the Horse year.

Experience the Energy Enhancement System™ \(EESystem\) as you rest in this supportive scalar field. Many experience profound relaxation, cellular rejuvenation, and a gentle resetting of the body’s natural balance—amplifying the effects of sound healing and creating an ideal foundation for welcoming the New Year with vitality, clarity, and grace.

Space is limited to 14 participants to preserve the intimacy and sacredness of the circle. Celebrate the Chinese New Year in resonance, rest, and renewal.

About Your Guides

Chris Young-Ginzburg, of Grove Circle Healing, is a seasoned clairvoyant and sound healer with nearly two decades of experience in Sonoma County. Chris weaves crystal singing bowls, tuning forks, and intuitive insight into transformative sound journeys that harmonize mind, body, and spirit. Their compassionate presence and depth of perception have guided countless people through profound healing and self-discovery.

Heather Star is a Cosmic Co-Creatress devoted to weaving commUNITY through sacred song and healing events. Trained in Mind-Body Medicine, she has facilitated hundreds of group healing circles, guiding participants into embodied awareness and soulful integration.  Heather’s voice was powerfully activated through Chris Young-Ginzburg’s Sound & Voice Activation work, and together they now offer deeply attuned sound journeys that open hearts and awaken inner wisdom.

Seraflame | Healing Harmonic Collaboration Chris Young-Ginzburg and Heather Star are also core members of Seraflame, a healing harmonic collaboration devoted to anchoring light through sacred song and frequency. Together, they create channeled soundscapes designed to support emotional healing, energetic coherence, and planetary awakening.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

You will be introduced you to the wonders of the Sonoma Coast and share how you can help steward California’s natural communities. Through the University of California Naturalist Program, participants become active members in a growing movement of conservation, community science, and volunteer activism.  Click here for more information: https://stewardscr.org/events/2026-u-c-california-naturalist-certification-winter-spring/

Coastal Sonoma County’s unique ecosystem has been described as the place where Canada meets Mexico. Where temperate rainforest shakes hands with scrubby chaparral. description:
Join us at the Vallejo Brewing Company to discuss monthly book themes! In celebration of Black History Month, the theme this month will be: African-American/Black Authors. Black History Month is an annually observed month-long celebration of African American life, History, and culture. Founded by Dr. Carter G. Woodson in February 1926, it is a month-long celebration to promote, research, preserve, interpret, and disseminate information about Black life, History, and culture. Please feel free to pick a book you believe fits into this theme and join the discussion. Questions/comments? Email Francesca, fgbains@solanocounty.gov. Free Event website

description:
Announcing the 35th Annual Mardi Gras Mambofest! The Big Annual Tradition lives on in downtown Petaluma — and it’s time to dance.

Join us Fat Tuesday, February 17 at the Mystic Theatre for an electrifying Fat Tuesday Dance Concert + street parade, featuring an all-star lineup of Rhythmtown-Jive favorites and special guests.

 Featuring musicians from Rhythmtown-Jive: Snakebite Jacobs • Kevin Zuffi • Tim Eschliman • Rene Jenkins

 Plus special guests: Johnny Bones & Beau Beaullieu (The California Honeydrops) Keta Bill • Katie Guthorn • Kathy Kennedy (Big Bang Beat)

 These incredible players have performed with legends including Etta James, Commander Cody, Joe Louis Walker, Natalie Cole, Mary Wilson, Smokey Robinson, and many more.

title: Adult Gymnastics Class
description:
We’re offering Adult Gymnastics Classes for the 18\+ crowd!

Adult Gymnastics classes occur every Tuesday & Friday from 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM.

$20 per person, OR pay for a whole 8-week session in advance through our site. You can attend on Tuesday, Friday, or both!

Please bring the class fee in cash at the time of arrival. This can be a DROP IN, so there is no need to sign up online before coming!

If you’ve ever wanted to try out gymnastics or get back into it in adulthood, now is your chance! During our adult classes, open to all genders, our coaches will move at the pace of each student, helping them achieve goals they set for themselves. No experience is necessary to be involved in this class, so this is a great opportunity to learn the basics and get some exercise, no matter what age you are! Try out our trampoline, bars, beam, and other gym equipment in a safe and supportive environment. You can build strength and increase your range of motion while having fun like you’re a kid again.

Ask our coaches what you can work on between classes, and they’ll help personalize your training!

Please wear something comfortable and keep long hair tied back. Skirts and restrictive clothing are not recommended. You must remove your shoes before going onto the mat or using equipment. Please let us know if you have any physical limitations or health conditions that may interfere with doing certain motions. We recommend bringing a water bottle.

You can email us for more info or join our mailing list at: info@sonomagymnasticsacademy.com

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we’ll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We’ll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We’ll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary — rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.

Date & Time: Tuesdays @ 6:30PM – 7:30PM

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Alibi Bookshop Book Club: The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store by James McBride
description:
NOTE: THIS IS THE 3RD THURSDAY DUE TO SCHEDULING CONFLICTS Please join us on Thursday, February 19th at 7pm to discuss "The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store" by James McBride! THE RUNAWAY NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER - A NEW YORK TIMES NOTABLE BOOK - A NEW YORK TIMES READERS PICK: 100 BEST BOOKS OF THE 21ST CENTURY WINNER OF THE 2024 LIBRARY OF CONGRESS PRIZE FOR AMERICAN FICTION FROM ONE OF TIME MAGAZINE'S 100 MOST INFLUENTIAL PEOPLE OF 2024 NAMED A BEST BOOK OF THE YEAR BY NPR/FRESH AIR, WASHINGTON POST, THE NEW YORKER, AND TIME MAGAZINE ONE OF BARACK OBAMA'S FAVORITE BOOKS OF 2023 "A murder mystery locked inside a Great American Novel . . . Charming, smart, heart-blistering, and heart-healing." -Danez Smith, The New York Times Book Review "We all need-we all deserve-this vibrant, love-affirming novel that bounds over any difference that claims to separate us." -Ron Charles, The Washington Post In 1972, when workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, were digging the foundations for a new development, the last thing they expected to find was a skeleton at the bottom of a well. Who the skeleton was and how it got there were two of the long-held secrets kept by the residents of Chicken Hill, the dilapidated neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side and shared ambitions and sorrows. Chicken Hill was where Moshe and Chona Ludlow lived when Moshe integrated his theater and where Chona ran the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state came looking for a deaf boy to institutionalize him, it was Chona and Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe's theater and the unofficial leader of the Black community on Chicken Hill, who worked together to keep the boy safe. As these characters' stories overlap and deepen, it becomes clear how much the people who live on the margins of white, Christian America struggle and what they must do to survive. When the truth is finally revealed about what happened on Chicken Hill and the part the town's white establishment played in it, McBride shows us that even in dark times, it is love and community-heaven and earth-that sustain us. Books available in the shop, online \(and e-book\), and audio.  Event website

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Bachata with ALEX
description:
Bachata with ALEX

Ready to take your bachata to the next level?

This intermediate bachata class is for dancers who have already mastered the basics and are ready for a new challenge. We’ll build on your foundation with a focus on more intricate footwork, technique, and partner work.

Advanced turn patterns and combinations

Styling and body movement to add flair to your dancing

Musicality to connect with the rhythm and emotion of the music

Feeling comfortable with your basic bachata steps and ready for more?

Our intermediate bachata class is designed for dancers who want to elevate their skills. We’ll move beyond the fundamentals to focus on more complex technique, footwork, and partner work.

This class will help you:

Refine your leading and following

Learn combinations and techniques

Develop your personal style and musicality

If you’re ready to add some fire to your dancing, this is the class for you!

Important Details

Basic steps and turns required. We’ll be moving into combinations, so a solid grasp of your basic steps is essential.

No partner necessary: Come solo or bring a friend—either way, you’ll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear non-marking shoe soles: This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can’t wait to see you on the dance floor.

title: Ash Wednesday
description:
Begin your Lenten journey with us on Ash Wednesday, a sacred day of reflection, repentance, and renewal.

​

7 AM – Imposition of Ashes A brief, contemplative service with the imposition of ashes—a quiet and prayerful way to mark the beginning of Lent.

​

12 PM – Ash Wednesday Eucharist

A full Eucharistic service with the imposition of ashes, grounding us in the season’s call to spiritual renewal.

​

7 PM - Silent Meditation with Imposition of Ashes A quiet, contemplative service centered on silence and prayer, with the imposition of ashes, offering space for reflection and renewal at the start of Lent.

​

All are welcome to join us as we step into this holy season together.

title: Morning Pranayama - Yogic Breathwork
description:
Nataraja School of Traditional Yoga
**Morning Pranayama - Traditional Yogic Breathwork with Kara Weimer**
**Wednesdays 8:30-9:30am**

Start your morning with traditional yogic breathwork beginning with purification techniques. Release toxins, clear and align the energy channels, strengthen the lungs, massage, tone & nourish internal organs, strengthen agni & digestion, oxygenate and improve blood flow, strengthen immunity & clear the mind. Implement various techniques to energize, focus & calm the mind & nervous system & harness the vital life force energy - with kumbhaka & bandha (breath holds and internal locks). Known to increase neuroplasticity, nitric oxide, and erase old mental and emotional patterns. Traditionally, pranayama is the doorway to access higher states of consciousness.

Throughout the ongoing class different practices will be presented. Learn Cleansing kriyas, Himalayan Pranayama including including Ujjayi Variations, Heating & Cooling Breaths, Solar, Lunar & Soli-Lunar Nadi Shuddhi practices, Samantraka Pranayama, Mudra, Pratyahara, Subtle & Contemplative Practices. Includes Pranava techniques for contemplation and merging with the vibration and sound of Om and Nada - internal sound current.

Please practice on an empty stomach.

Soft Medicine - Downstairs in Ananhata Studio
$25 - Drop in, Discounted Class Passes & Membership Options
You can [pre-register here](https://momence.com/u/soft-medicine-sanctuary-riBGtr)

title: Renewed in Nature at Jack London State Historic Park
description:
Join a restorative wellness gathering set within the natural beauty of Jack London State Historic Park. Surrounded by towering redwoods and peaceful landscapes, this experience invites you to slow down, reconnect with nature, and find a sense of connection.  As part of the park’s seasonal programming, this event celebrates the quiet magic of winter and the sense of renewal that comes with the start of a new year. Explore gentle forest trails, allowing the sights, sounds, and stillness of the forest to calm the mind and refresh the spirit. Enjoy a guided walk with moments of reflection, forest bathing, and gentle yoga, all designed to help you feel grounded and refreshed. Step into the forest, embrace the season, and leave feeling renewed. This hike will be about 3.5 miles roundtrip on uneven terrain. Sturdy walking shoes and weather appropriate layers are recommended.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: BLS Certification Class (American Heart Association)
description:
BLS Certification Class \(AHA\) - In Person, Instructor-Led

American Heart Association BLS certification class \(in-person, instructor-led class in our Rohnert Park classroom\). BLS \(Basic Life Support\) is the required CPR class for healthcare providers. Includes cardiac and respiratory arrest management, CPR, AED use, and choking treatment for all ages. This class is appropriate for initial BLS or BLS renewal.

Vive CPR is an American Heart Association \(AHA\) Training Site. AHA "BLS Provider" certifications are issued on the same day.

We also offer Blended Learning BLS certification courses \(online course plus in-person Skills Session\).

Learn from a top-rated, local CPR training company with over 900 5-star reviews! Our classes are fun, engaging, and expertly taught by experienced first responders.

Learn More & Enroll: https://vivecpr.com/class/bls-certification/

Questions? Call/text \(707\) 612-3277 or https://vivecpr.com/contact

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian
