title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Art Of Acrylics
description:
Suzanne will demonstrate each week as students follow along with weekly painting projects, exploring techniques such as layering thick and thin paint, using gels and palette knife, and applying color theories. Students can work on their own projects as well. Whether you're a beginner or looking to refine your skills, this class covers everything you need to know. You'll get informed instruction on how to begin a piece, from choosing the right materials to selecting the perfect color palette. We'll dive into composition techniques to help you craft a balanced, captivating piece, and walk you through the finishing touches that bring your work to life. Suzanne's artwork ranges from portraits, figurative genre, landscapes and caricatures. She has exhibited in juried shows including The Society of Illustrators in New York and for 10 years at the Southern California Laguna Beach Art Festival. She has taught classes and workshops for many years and led lecture-demos at art associations from California to Washington State. For enrollment and supply list, please text or call Suzanne Carson at 707 888 2083

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney’s Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

description:
**WHAT:** Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description:
Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

description:
Schedule

Wednesday, March 11 – April 22, 2026 11:00 AM – 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

Intermediate

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$225 – Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20″ x 26″ drawing board with clips, 18 “x 24” Strathmore drawing pad \(other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality\), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal \(Char-kole brand black\), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black \(one fine-tip and one medium-tip\).Membership has its benefits

FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.

Sonoma County artists, Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich present the Color of Love, paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features Laura Roney’s Dance!, a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. \(707\) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    www.upstairsart gallery.net

Source: Press Democrat

title: Mid
description:
We invite you to discover Dutton-Goldfield during our quieter midweek hours with The Midweek Flight—a limited-time, FREE tasting experience designed for exploration, connection, and ease.

Offered Monday through Wednesday from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM, this experience invites guests to enjoy a curated flight of only 3 pours total at our tasting bar, featuring wines that highlight our Russian River Valley roots and single-vineyard focus.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:
WHAT: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

DATE:            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

TIME: 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

WHERE:       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

LINK:             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

DETAILS:

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         Offered Daily: 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

·         Experience length: 2 hours

·         Wines: Selections of library, limited single-vineyard, and a barrel tasting of yet-to-be-released Cabernet Sauvignon

·         Cost: $150 per Person

·         Exclusive Member Price: $95 per Member

ADMISSION: Members $95 | Non-members $150

Source: Press Democrat

title: Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
A relaxed and elegant garden experience! Your host will guide you through a tasting of our Russian River Valley estate wines. In inclement weather, this experience will be hosted in our charming tasting room.

Enhance your visit with an option to add-on cheese & charcuterie or artisanal chocolates to make your wine country experience even more delightful.

$40 per guest | Refundable with two bottle purchase

Club Member: Four Complimentary Tastings per Visit

Source: Press Democrat

title: Picnic Lunch and Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
Begin your wine-tasting experience with a guided tasting led by our host, who will introduce you to our exclusive estate Russian River Valley wines. Once you have found your favorite, choose a glass from our specialty curated wine flight to enjoy with a delicious picnic lunch, prepared by our local partners at Willow Wood Market & Cafe. Reservations required with advanced booking of 48 hours.

$85 per guest | Club Member: $45 per guest

Source: Press Democrat

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

Source: Press Democrat

1:00-1:15: Introductions

1:15-2:15: Write in silence for 1 hour

title: Create A Digital Story
description:
What is a digital story? A digital story is a narrated slideshow or movie that you voice over with your own personal story or poem. Bring a flash drive or email yourself 10-20 photos, or up to 5 short videos, that you would like to include in your story. If you can't decide or aren't ready to share, we will have some images available to get you started. Consider attending the iMovie Editing class to get a head start on your project. description:

 An outsider in a new town and a new school, Delilah seeks comfort in the pages of her favorite book, where she feels heard and understood by the handsome Prince Oliver. But as the lines between fantasy and reality begin to blur in extraordinary ways, Delilah realizes her dreams in the real world are worth fighting for.

title: Wise Girl Workshops - School Year Wellness Workshops
description:
Whose ready to be a part of an amazing group of girls and youth who are open minded and hearted—ready to make new friends AND develop essential life skills to help them learn to live well?

We are now enrolling for our School Year Wellness Workshops for girls in 3rd-8th grades.

Meeting for a full 15 weeks, members make fantastic friendships, have fun engaging in activities and art projects, and learn social-emotional-physical tools that will help them throughout their lifetime.

We’ve got 3 amazing facilitators and workshops are hosted at McKinley School in Petaluma-though members come from a variety of schools and towns to attend opening up even further opportunities for making even more friends!

\*Grades 3/4 meets on Wednesday's from Jan 14-May 13

\*Grades 5/6 meets on Tuesday's Jan 13-May 12

\*Additional Grades 5/6 meets on Wednesdays from Jan 14-May 13

\*Grades 7/8 meets on Thursday's from Jan 15-May 14

Ready to learn more and register?

wisegirlworkshops.com/workshops-and-services/school-year-wellness-workshop-series/

Here’s to growing Wise Girls and Youth!

$100 – Registration Cost

Master the art of empanada making with both sweet and savory fillings. Learn dough techniques, folding methods, and create delicious handheld pastries.

What you’ll do

Discover the versatility of empanadas in this hands-on culinary class where you’ll master both sweet and savory variations of this beloved pastry. Learn to create tender, flaky dough from scratch and explore traditional filling techniques that balance flavor and texture. You’ll prepare savory empanadas with options like seasoned beef, chicken, cheese and vegetables, alongside sweet versions featuring fruit, chocolate, or dulce de leche. Instruction covers proper dough handling, folding and crimping techniques for beautiful presentation, and cooking methods including baking and frying. You’ll understand how to adjust moisture levels in fillings to prevent soggy pastries and learn tips for making empanadas ahead for easy entertaining. Whether you’re drawn to traditional Latin American recipes or creative fusion flavors, this class gives you the skills to make professional-quality empanadas at home. Perfect for both beginners and experienced cooks looking to expand their pastry repertoire.

title: Creative Flow: Explore, Create, Renew
description:
Schedule

Wednesdays, February 4 – February 25, 2026 5:30 PM – 8:30 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Categories: Drawing & Painting, Wellness

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$200 – Registration Cost $25 – Materials Fee $225 – Total Registration CostExplore body, mind, and imagination through movement, art, and writing in this beginner-friendly, four-week class. No experience needed-just curiosity!

What you’ll do

Based on the Tamalpa Life/Art Process, founded by Anna Halprin, this four-week class invites participants to explore the connection between body, mind, and imagination through gentle movement, art-making, and writing. Each session blends simple, creative activities designed to transform life experiences into art and open new possibilities for personal renewal. In a supportive and beginner-friendly environment, students will deepen self-awareness, express emotions, and discover fresh perspectives. No prior dance or art experience is required—just curiosity and an open heart. Course Format and Weekly Outline: Session 1 – The Call & Crossing the Threshold: Mapping the Self Theme: Where am I now? Practices: Guided movement warm-up; sensory awareness; movement exploration of stepping toward/away from a “threshold”; body mapping with paint/collage; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants identify their current state and set creative intentions for the series. Session 2 – Trials & Allies: Shadows and Strengths Theme: Meeting obstacles and discovering resources. Practices: Movement exploration of “allies and shadows”; expressive drawing/painting; optional mask or small clay object; reflective writing; small-group witnessing. Outcome: Students recognize inner strengths and gain flexible tools for navigating emotions and challenges. Session 3 – Ordeal & Transformation: Release and the Boon Theme: Releasing old patterns and discovering new insights. Practices: Grounding movement; movement ritual exploring “what I am ready to release”; creation of the “Boon” object or image; reflective writing. Outcome: Participants experience personal renewal and create a symbolic object representing newly gained insight. Session 4 – Return with the Elixir: Integration & Wholeness Theme: Carrying creative insight back into everyday life. Practices: Movement exploration of “pathways of return”; creation of a triptych \(Before / Crossing / Return\); gallery walk and group witnessing; closing ritual with shared intentions. Outcome: Students integrate learning and leave with practical creative practices for ongoing self- discovery and stress relief. Learning Outcomes: 1. Develop greater self-awareness by exploring personal experiences through movement, art-making, and reflective writing. 2. Use creative tools for well-being, including techniques for emotional expression, personal renewal, and stress reduction. 3. Strengthen confidence and connection through supportive group activities and experiments with expressive movement and visual art.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Cool Team Leader Info Session
description:
Climate change and social division are threatening to drastically and irrevocably damage life on Earth. But, you don't have to act alone to protect Earth for future generations!

We know individual actions done privately won't move the needle. By taking action collectively and publicly we can create a culture shift, and that is where the real power is.

Our Cool Team program brings neighbors or friends together so that we can take care of each other while we take care of the planet.

Join us for a one-hour interactive information session that will help you experience what it will be like to be a Cool Team Leader so you can decide if you are ready to step up and take the half-day Team. Leader training.

Come learn more and enjoy FREE PIZZA!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Writers Forum
description:
Author Samantha Rose will discuss the truths that emerged while writing "Giving Up the Ghost" and how they shifted the story she was telling on the page, and also the story she'd been telling herself for much of her life.

We'll discuss how to navigate the truth when writing about family members and other loved ones.

We'll learn about the healing and transformative power of writing about the hardest, scariest and most deeply buried things, and how channeling these stories onto the page can set us free.

Age\(s\)

$265 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $295 – Total Registration Cost

A continuation of our intermediate course, this upper level / advanced course will help you hone your throwing skills in the studio.

What you’ll Create

This session is designed for people who have already taken multiple wheel throwing courses. A continuation of our intermediate course, this upper level / advanced course will help you hone your throwing skills through more complex demos, and nuanced approaches to technical throwing. In this 8 week course, students will dive deep into developing their own unique voice as they build a technical toolset for the independent maker. In addition to throwing, surface decoration techniques will be explored as well as the opportunity to experiment with different clay bodies. With your 8 week class registration, students receive the opportunity to purchase a studio pass for ½ off during the duration of their class. Sign ups for membership will be included in your preclass email.

Membership has its benefits

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

description:

We will have some specimens to touch and smell. Fork in the Path offers forest-to-table learning programs for the adventurous of all ages across Northern California. Programming includes mushroom and plant foraging, tasting wild food, cultivating a respectful and reciprocal relationship with the land, making art, and community building.

Our Adult Beginner Tap Class is the perfect place to let loose, learn the basics, and enjoy the rhythm of tap dance.

About the class

Ready to make some noise and have some fun? Our Adult Beginner Tap Class is the perfect place to let loose, learn the basics, and enjoy the rhythm of tap dance — no experience necessary! Each week, you’ll learn a brand-new mini routine that combines classic steps with modern flair. Whether you’re dancing for the first time or returning after years away, this class is designed to be accessible, upbeat, and full of energy. Come for the tap, stay for the laughs, and leave feeling empowered \(and a little more rhythmic than before\). Lace up your tap shoes – it’s your time to shine! Note: If you do not have tap shoes, you can wear socks to the class.

title: Wednesday Night Comedy Open Mic
description:
Wednesday Night Comedy Open Mic-Downtown Santa Rosa. No cover, free popcorn, Bay Area comics, & a fun crowd whether you go up or just watch.

Wednesday nights are for working it out, trying new jokes, and laughing with the local comedy community at Wednesday Night Comedy Open Mic at Barrel Proof Lounge in Downtown Santa Rosa .

This is a lively, welcoming open mic that draws comedians from all over the Bay Area and beyond. Whether you’re getting on stage or just grabbing a drink and enjoying the show, it’s always a fun, unpredictable night.

title: Big Stage Karaoke Wednesdays with KJ Danny D
description:
Wednesday nights at Barrel Proof Lounge just got louder, sexier, and way more fun.

Karaoke moves to the main showroom big stage every Wednesday at 9pm, following Open Mic, and runs until late. Hosting the night is KJ Danny D (Danny Duclos)—one of the most popular and in-demand karaoke hosts around. We’re genuinely stoked to have him bringing his style, energy, and crowd-moving presence to Downtown Santa Rosa.

This isn’t sleepy bar karaoke. Danny brings a fresh, high-energy approach that turns singing into a full-on late-night experience. Big stage, great sound, packed room, and the kind of momentum that keeps people singing well past closing time.

title: Cheese & Butter Classes
description:
Join award-winning cheesemaker Sheana Davis and wine expert Ben Sessions for unforgettable cheese and butter making classes. Perfect for team building, celebrations, and educational events, our classes are interactive, fun, and easy for everyone. 

From classes on how to make Creme de Ricotta wheel to Mozzarella Pulling to butter-making classes, guests will always leave with a creamy treat to take home \(if it makes it that far!\) – so bring a small cooler with you.  

Food has a remarkable ability to bring people together. 

Cheesemaking classes are perfect for team-building activities, company meetings, team celebrations, staff events, corporate fun, bridal parties, couples classes, girlfriend getaway weekends, LGBT events, EBT education courses, and more. Classes held year-round on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 12:00-2:00 and 3:30-5:30pm. 

See the full schedule of all our cheese and butter making classes here.  

With each class, we give back to the community by providing meals for food-insecure seniors in Sonoma Valley. After learning how to make cheese, our guests can prepare these meals and write personal notes for the seniors on the lids.  

Join us in making a positive impact while having fun and learning a new skill.   

Your Cheesemaking Experience: 



Begin with local wine and an artisanal cheese tasting.

Learn to make cheese and compound butter with everyday ingredients and tools.

Enjoy specialized classes for dishes like lasagna and gourmet grilled cheeses.

Exclusive guest cheesemakers often share their techniques.

Ideal for corporate events, bridal parties, getaways, and more.



Sheana and Ben pride themselves on using ingredients readily available in any local grocery store, with cooking supplies used reside in most home cooks’ kitchens. Guest cheesemakers are often available to showcase their own cheeses and techniques, making the class a truly unique experience. 

Check the schedule for Wine Country-based cheesemaking classes.  

Customize Your Class:To arrange private or corporate classes at venues like Sonoma Fairmont Mission Inn or Silverado Resort, contact us at sheanadavis@gmail.com. We can help create a unique and unforgettable experience for your entire group! Private and corporate classes may be arranged and are hosted at various Wine Country venues, including The Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn, Silverado Resort, The Lodge in Sonoma, and private homes and estates. 

To register: 

https://theepicureanconnection.com/events/

Source: Press Democrat

Explore the bounty of summer at the Marin Farmers Markets. Taste vine-ripened tomatoes, corn that was picked that morning, and peaches so juicy you have to bend over just to get a bite. Farm-fresh eggs, grass-fed beef, artisan c heeses, raw milk, and freshly baked breads complete the shopping exper ience. Specialty prepared foods and handmade art add to the magic of the market.

Enjoy the intimate feeling of the Thursday Marin Farmers Market, an ideal place to meet for lunch and pick up fresh produce for the weekend. Turn your dollar into a vote for local sustainable agriculture, shrink your eco-footprint, and revive the feeling of being intimate ly connected to your food by meeting your farmers face-to-face. title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Yoga Vinyasa Krama
description:
Nataraja School of Traditional Yoga
**Yoga Vinyasa Krama - Thursdays 9-10:30am**
**Soft Medicine Sanctuary - Loft**

Experience physical health & fitness, pranic flow, vital energy & stillness - through intelligent architecture with the metaphysics of deep conscious breathing & slow motion, yogic breathwork, mantra/sound/vibration, mudra, subtle & contemplative practices.

Yoga Vinyasa Krama is a comprehensive hatha-raja yogic system for purification, developing concentration, neuromuscular fitness and conditioning, mastering the breath, awakening subtle energy and stilling the mind. Based on deep breathing & the subtle movement of prana directed into the cartilage tissue, sinuous musculature, internal organs, nerve pathways and nadis. It has over 700 intelligently sequenced slow, conscious breath powered with precision movement variations with pause (vinyasas), exploring many aesthetic variations of each posture to correctly establish the main asanas while the mind merges with the breath.
Includes drishti, pratikriyas, bandha, vaseth, mudra, mantra, surya & ding namaskar with breath & mantra, cleansing kriyas, Himalayan pranayama including including ujjayi variations, heating & cooling breaths, solar, lunar & soli-lunar nadi shuddhi practices, pranava & samantraka pranayama, pratyahara, subtle & contemplative practices in 12 kramas (sequences).

The whole process gradually transforms the body and mind, releasing old patterns of physical and mental tension and dysfunctional patterns of movement, providing tonic, energetic and psychophysiological effects. This system is presented from the teachings Srivatsa Ramaswami learned through his over 33 years of one on one study with Sri Krishnamacharya and teachings from a similar Himalayan method.

This ongoing class will explore the entire system of 12 Kramas with each class focusing on a particular krama (sequence) & pranayama & contemplative practices.

Please practice on an empty stomach. Morning beverage ok but please take it 30min or more before class.

$25 Drop In, Discounted Class Passes & Memberships
Register -[https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true](https://momence.com/Soft-Medicine-Sanctuary/Yoga-Vinyasa-Krama-/122789095?skipPreview=true)

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Shut Up & Write!® at Redwood Café in Cotati (in person)
description:
Shut Up & Write!® Wine Country
**Coworking for writers in Cotati!**
Join us for some focused writing time. All experience levels are welcome, and don’t worry, no one will see what you've written. This session is about WRITING, whether you're working on a novel, memoir, play, short story, dissertation, job application, blog, poetry, journal, or song.

**Format**
10:00 - 10:15 AM: Introduce yourself and what you're working on today
10:15 - 11:30 AM: Write in silence for 1 hour and 15 minutes.
11:30 - 11:45 AM: Check in with one another and share how it went

**Venue Details:**

* Redwood Cafe has WiFi for guests
* Ample street parking is available
* Please thank our hosts by purchasing something
* If music or ambient noise are distracting, please bring ear plugs or headphones
* Outlets are available if you need to charge your laptop

title: Cuentos con Ritmo (Stories with Rhythm)
description:
Cuentos con Ritmo \(Stories with Rhythm\)

Cuentos con Ritmo | Cuentos \* Música \* Movimiento 

Presentado por Colors of Spanish 

Cuentos con Ritmo es una oportunidad única semanal para niños de 1 a 5 años y sus familias, el cual aporta alegría, comprensión y aprecio por la lengua española a toda la comunidad. Durante Cuentos con Ritmo, los pequeños visitantes y sus familias participan de forma lúdica en historias interactivas con música y movimiento fortaleciendo nuestra diversa comunidad y entusiasmo por la lengua meta. 

Cuentos con Ritmo es presentado por Guadalupe Tausch en colaboración con la organización que fundó, Colors of Spanish. Originaria del estado de Guanajuato en México, tiene una maestría en español con énfasis en la adquisición de una segunda lengua para la primera infancia y continúa sus estudios enfocada en la primera infancia especializándose en la adquisición de idiomas a través de la música/movimiento. Colors of Spanish ofrece talleres para profesores, bibliotecarios y cuidadores y organiza programas de cuentos en español con música y movimiento en escuelas, bibliotecas y museos locales. www.colorsofspanish.org 

Cuentos con Ritmo | Cuentos \* Música \* Movimiento 

Presented by Colors of Spanish 

Cuentos con Ritmo \(Stories with Rhythm\) is a weekly one-of-a-kind opportunity for children ages 1-5 and their families that brings joy, understanding and appreciation for the Spanish language to Spanish- and English-speaking speakers alike. During Cuentos con Ritmo, young visitors and their families playfully engage in interactive stories with music and movement that build community and an excitement for language! 

Cuentos con Ritmo is presented by Guadalupe Tausch in collaboration with the organization she founded, Colors of Spanish. Originally from the state of Guanajuato in México, she has a master’s degree in Spanish with emphasis in second language acquisition for early childhood and continues her study of childhood and music/movement trainings. Colors of Spanish provides workshops for teachers, librarians and caregivers and hosts Spanish story time with music & movement programs at local schools, libraries, and museums. www.colorsofspanish.org 

Designed for kids 1-5, families, and siblings.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

**FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE**

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

**RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.**

Sonoma County artists, **Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich** present the **Color of Love,** paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features **Laura Roney’s Dance!,** a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. (707) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    **www.upstairsart gallery.net**

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description:
Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Art Exhibit:  Color of Love
description:
Date: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  1/15/26

FEBRURY EXHIBIT: COLOR OF LOVE

EXHIBIT DATES:  January 26 – February 22, 2026

RECEPTION: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2026, 3 – 5 pm: Join in to meet the artists, celebrate the show and welcome the season of love. Take part in the Gallery’s free monthly drawing for a beautiful work by a Gallery artist.  Refreshments will be served.

Sonoma County artists, Linda Barretta, Nancy Gray, Bev Haley, Phyllis Rapp, Donna Schaffer, Tosya Shore, Luba Stolper and Gen Zorich present the Color of Love, paintings that bring out the excitement and fun of the Valentine season.  Red takes a starring role in these works set against a broad spectrum of complementary violets, blues, and greens.  In Gray’s “Love Abstractly” an iconic heart is transformed through bold splashes of color.  Stolper brings us delicious red delights in her “Bowl of Strawberries,”  fruit rendered so realistically, one’s mouth waters.  Paintings by Haley, Schaffer and Zorich celebrate the coming of Spring with color-rich floral displays – tulips and scarlet buglers.  Rapp and Barretta offer a nod to our feathered and furry friends. Barretta’s jaunty raven cocks his head as he offers up a heart on a red ribbon in “Raven Heart” and Rapp’s little fox peers at us from a bed of flowers in “Foxy Flowers.”  Shore’s “Showering You with Gifts” catches our eye with a sleek figure sporting a stunning red umbrella.  “As we welcome the sunnier days and flowers in the fields, Valentine’s Day with its rich color palette is such a glorious way to celebrate the seasonal transition,” noted Gray.   

The Stairway Smallworks Showcase features Laura Roney’s Dance!, a collection of works that explores dance in its many forms. Part of cultures throughout the world, dance expression takes on styles that can be structured, such as ballet, or, by contrast, free flowing.  And dance is a beloved part of the dating scene, whether slow-dancing or rocking out.  In “Hold Me Tight” one feels the close connection of the couple dancing on Valentine’s Day.  Another couple joyfully whoops it up in “Bust a Move.” Bring on the music – these works make one want to get a move on.

Meet the artist: Roney will be hosting the Gallery on February 1 and 27 from 11am to 6 pm.

Upstairs Art Gallery, 306 Center Street, Healdsburg, CA 95448. \(707\) 431-4214.: OPEN DAILY: 11am – 6 pm.    www.upstairsart gallery.net

title: Practice Public Speaking at Downtown Toastmasters
description:
Our meeting theme on January 8th is "Room to Grow." You are welcome to practice your public speaking with a 1-2 minute table topic extemporaneous speeches from a prompt. What better way to start the New Year by taking the first step into confident public speaking?

We start the meetings promptly at 12:05pm, so come early to sign in and mingle. We are a small group and meet twice monthly. It's not overwhelming and there's plenty of chances to participate.

Ready to boost your public speaking skills? Come hang out with fellow enthusiasts and practice in a super friendly, in-person setting. Whether you're a newbie or a pro, Downtown Toastmasters is all about growing your confidence and connecting with awesome people. Don't miss out on a great chance to speak up and shine!

Guests Welcome!

title: Arts Guild of Sonoma Presents: For the Love of Art
description:
For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma. The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. Learn more at  artsguildofsonoma.org .

title: Thursday Pottery on the Wheel; All Levels
description:
Thursdays, January 29 – March 19, 2026 2:00 PM – 5:00 PM

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Ceramics

Age\(s\)

17\+

$265 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $295 – Total Registration Cost

Deborah Donahower takes you through the fundamentals of working with clay in on the wheel in this 8 week course.

What you’ll do

Deborah Donahower takes you through the fundamentals of working with clay in on the wheel in this 8 week course. Designed for all levels \(beginners and those more experienced\) Deborah thoughtfully explores the tried and true techniques of ceramic work with her students through structured assignments, allowing her students to develop their own creative voice in the process.Students will receive instruction in wheel work, glazing, and finishing pieces. With your 8 week class registration, students receive the opportunity to purchase a studio pass for ½ off during the duration of their class. Sign ups for membership will be included in your pre class email.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 117, Ceramics Studio

title: Barbies & Bags Workshop
location:
Bags! In addition to dolls, we’re expanding the exhibit to include bags—think totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It’s a joy to see your art find a new home—and to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

Source: North Bay Bohemian
description:
Schedule

Sunday, February 15, 2026 1:00 PM – 4:00 PM

Location

Room 201, Fiber Arts Studio

Experience Level

All Levels

Kids, Programming, Sustainability

Age\(s\)

All Ages are welcome to attend Children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult

$25 – One Bag or Doll Entry $40 – Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 – 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we’ll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we’re expanding the exhibit to include bags—think totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It’s a joy to see your art find a new home—and to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

title: Home Is Where The Art Is
description:
Celebrate creativity and the power of self-expression at Home Is Where the Art Is art showcase featuring works by eight resident artists from HomeFirst’s Emergency Interim Housing community, Labath Landing in Rohnert Park. ​ ​ The showcase is the culmination of a six-week therapeutic art workshop series, led by Ani Sher, a Bay Area artist and community activator based in Petaluma and owner of Slough City Studios. The series was designed to foster connection, build skills, encourage self-expression and build community.​

​ Enjoy wine, light refreshments, and delicious bites by Sally Tomatoes as you explore the artwork that tells stories of resilience and hope. ​ ​ 100% of art sales go directly to the participating artists, so every purchase makes a meaningful impact. A 15% buyer’s premium is included to support Homefirst’s programs and services.​

​ Thank you to our sponsors, Hedge Realty, Community Foundation Sonoma County, and City of Petaluma for their support of this event.​ ​

Join us as we explore what home, hope and belonging means through art and personal storytelling.​

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Latin Cooking Class with Chef Carlos of Guiso Latin Fusion
description:
Latin Cooking Class with Chef Carlos of Guiso Latin Fusion - 2/19

$125.00

Join Sonoma Family Meal and locally-renowned chef Carlos Mojica of Guiso Latin Fusion in Healdsburg for a Latin cooking class at the Sonoma Family Meal Kitchen! The hands-on, collaborative class will last 2.5 hours, with time to enjoy your meal together at the end.

Whether you’re a seasoned cook or just starting out, this class will offer a fun, engaging learning environment, while raising funds for Sonoma Family Meal’s free culinary job training and food-security programs.

If you haven’t been to the SFM Kitchen yet, this class is also the perfect chance to visit and experience where the magic takes place and how the work gets done.

WHEN: Thursday February 19th, 5-7:30pm WHERE: SFM community kitchen, 1370A Redwood Way, Petaluma

THE MENU: TBD

ABOUT THE CHEF:

Chef Carlos was born in El Salvador, where his passion for cooking began in the kitchen with his grandmother and mother, creating simple yet flavorful family meals. After his family migrated to the United States, Carlos worked at his uncle’s restaurant in Sebastopol, further deepening his love for food. While attending Piner High School, in Santa Rosa, he joined a newly established culinary program, where he learned professional kitchen skills and participated in local food competitions with renowned chefs like Guy Fieri and Rich Nolan. In 2008, his high school team won first place in the Santa Rosa Iron Chef competition. During this time, Carlos also took on the responsibility of cooking family meals, solidifying his dream of becoming a chef. 

After graduating, Carlos started at Jackson’s in Santa Rosa as a dishwasher but quickly worked his way up through various kitchen roles, impressing his colleagues with his dedication and skill. His hard work caught the attention of two restaurateurs, who offered him a sous chef position at their new restaurant. While thriving in this role, Carlos realized his passion for showcasing Latin cuisine and decided to pursue further education. He earned an associate degree from Santa Rosa Junior College’s culinary program and took additional courses at the Culinary Institute of America \(CIA\) Greystone, St. Helena focusing on pastry and butchery. Next up, Chef Carlos was the head of food development at La Tortilla Factory in Santa Rosa, creating new recipes and products. 

At 24, Carlos saved $60,000 from playing in a popular, award winning family band and flipping a house with his father. In 2014, he found a small restaurant space in Healdsburg and, with his father as a partner, opened Guiso Latin Fusion on October 15, 2015. Drawing inspiration from Central and South America, Carlos built the restaurant’s reputation organically, eventually gaining recognition from a San Francisco Chronicle food writer, which propelled his success.

For Carlos, food is art, and every dish tells a story rooted in his culture and childhood. He strives to create a family-like atmosphere in his restaurant, where guests feel connected and leave with memorable experiences. Beyond running his restaurant, Carlos mentors young chefs, develops a rosé wine brand called BELI’S, and continues to “Live a Flavorful Life.” His motto, “Cook My Culture,” reflects his deep connection to his roots and his passion for creating meaningful culinary experiences.

AWARDS

\+Best Chef, 2025 Healdsburg, CA Healdsburg Tribune \+The 100 Best Restaurants in America by OpenTable 2025 \+Multiple Diners choice Awards in 2020, 2022, 2023, 2024, 2025 \+Top 100 places to eat in U.S 2024 by Yelp

Reserve my spot

title: Oil Painting Atelier: Guided Growth & Project Realization
description:
Thursdays, January 8 – February 26, 2026 5:00 PM – 8:00 PM

Experience Level

Intermediate and Advanced

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 – Registration Cost

A mentored studio for long-term oil painting projects with personalized guidance, weekly reviews, and support tailored to each artist’s level and goals.

What you’ll do

This continuous Atelier studio offers sustained, personalized mentorship for students working on long-term oil painting projects. It is structured to serve artists at various stages of development, from those applying foundational knowledge to advanced students exploring profound expressive concepts.

Phase 1: Project Proposal & Private Consultation: All students submit a project proposal. You will meet individually and privately with the instructor to define the scope, set challenging yet achievable goals based on your current skill level, and create a comprehensive roadmap for the duration of the course. This ensures a productive and focused experience, regardless of whether you are a recent beginner or an advanced painter.

Phase 2: Weekly Problem-Solving Studio: You work independently on your project, benefiting from the structure of a studio environment. The instructor conducts weekly, dedicated review time, providing customized guidance. This support scales precisely to your needs, ensuring you receive the appropriate technical advice to overcome obstacles specific to your project and your level of experience.

Integration with The Chromatic Voice \(taught on Monday mornings\): This course is the essential practical partner, ensuring that both foundational knowledge and advanced conceptual exploration are successfully translated into realized, high-quality paintings. Prerequisite: Students must have completed at least one introductory course in oil painting or demonstrate equivalent foundational knowledge \(e.g., knowledge of basic setup, brush cleaning, and layering principles\).

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 208

title: Sashiko Mending
description:
Schedule

Thursday, February 19, 2026 5:30 PM – 8:00 PM

Experience Level

Beginning

Event Category: Fiber Arts

Age\(s\)

13\+

Children under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult.

$50 – Registration Cost $10 – Materials Fee $60 – Total Registration CostLearn Sashiko mending: patch, reinforce, and decorate garments with traditional Japanese stitching. Practice on your clothes or provided fabric.

What you’ll do

This class introduces the technique of Sashiko mending. With humble beginnings in rural Japan, Sashiko’s running stitch insulated work garments for warmth and longevity. Learn how to patch and repair a rip or hole, reinforce a worn area, and prepare distressed textile in order to draw a Sashiko grid and stitch a pattern. Choose from a variety of traditional Sashiko patterns. Bring in one or two garments to assess for mending or decorating. Medium-weight, woven fabrics work best; such as denim, cotton or linen. If desired, students may simply practice a Sashiko pattern or two on sampler patches provided. All supplies are provided \(thread, needles, thimble, fabric to practice on, chalk, patterns, scraps to use as patches\). Students will take home their two needles, twenty-two yards of cotton Sashiko thread, and a Sashiko thimble.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

title: Profs & Pints Napa: The (New) Science of Attraction
description:
Profs and Pints Napa presents: “The \(New\) Science of Attraction,” on psychological research that’s upending assumptions about how we pick partners, with Paul W. Eastwick, professor of psychology at the University of California Davis and author of Bonded by Evolution: The New Science of Love and Connection.

Over the past few decades, a buzzy new branch of science, evolutionary psychology, has spread a deeply flawed story about romantic relationships. Cloaking itself in the language of incontrovertible Darwinian fact, it has popularized the idea that our minds have been shaped by primal drives that pit the genders against each other. It has promoted the myth that men are wired to be promiscuous and the notions that wealth, status, and beauty are the ultimate aphrodisiacs.

It’s time to say goodbye to such thinking and embrace a more-evolved view of romance, argues Paul W. Eastwick, who co-hosts the Love Factually podcast and operates a UC-Davis research lab that studies attraction and relationships.

Come to Napa Yards for a talk by Dr. Eastwick that will give you a much more sophisticated understanding of matters of the heart. 

Drawing from pathbreaking research—including original experiments from his own lab—he’ll offer the take that relationship success hinges on compatibility rather than finding someone who meets some universal ideal of a good partner.

He’ll show that while popularity factors into first impressions, its influence fades fast. When evaluating mutual friends and acquaintances they’ve known for months, single people barely agree in their ratings of who is or isn’t desirable as a dating partner.

Although men and women occasionally say they want different things out of romance, gender differences evaporate once we assess what men and women actually want. Attraction from ancestral times through the present is best depicted as a process of finding—and, often, creating—a compatible relationship.

Dr. Eastwick will show how the traits we often look for in a partner—personality, lifestyle, values, and humor—are poor predictors of compatibility. Instead, lasting attraction is built through the gradual forging of strong attachment bonds, through mundane moments in which people offer each other a “safe haven” and “secure base.”

Distilling evolutionary biology, anthropology, and psychology into accessible insights, he’ll explain why we so often choose dating strategies that make us miserable and how we can use a more evolved approach. \(Tickets available only online. Advance tickets: $13.50 plus processing fees. Doors: $17, or $15 with a student ID. Doors open at 5:30 and the talk begins at 6:30.\)

Image: “Love Match,” by Jan van Beers \(Wikimedia Commons\).

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Monthly Men's Circle - 3rd Thursday
location: The Unstruck Drum - Center for Shamanism
description:
This monthly gathering meets every third Thursday of each month. We have the intention of offering a safe space for all men who walk a path of seeking authenticity. Led by Collin Hoctor, this group brings community, shares wisdom, and brings healing to those who desire to walk a deeper, more meaningful life.

From Collin:

I am a psychotherapist and guide whose work weaves together spirituality, nature-based practices, psychedelic therapy, and recovery. My path has been shaped by a foundation in existential philosophy and psychology, medicine circles, and a lifelong study of contemplative and esoteric traditions. Out of my own longing for community and a commitment to the needs of the moment, I am passionate about creating spaces for men to gather in honesty, vulnerability, and authenticity — places where we can face our struggles, share our truths, and remember the healing power of connection.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Napa Bookmine Book Club: Colored Television by Danzy Senna
description:
Join us for a book club discussion! This year, 2026, Napa Bookmine Book Clubs' book picks will come straight from home, this year's Napa Bookmine BINGO Card! Each book will match a BINGO square. Hurrah! Play along with Napa Bookmine and read some new, fun books, and if you come to every meeting, you may get a BINGO in the meantime. ;\) This month, we'll be talking about Danzy Senna's Colored Television. This is a free event, but we would appreciate your RSVP so we can plan for your attendance! Questions? Email us at events@napabookmine.com ABOUT THE BOOK A NATIONAL BESTSELLER | A GOOD MORNING AMERICA BOOK CLUB PICK | A WASHINGTON POST TOP 10 BOOK OF THE YEAR | A NEW YORK TIMES NOTABLE BOOK OF 2024 “A laugh-out-loud cultural comedy… This is the New Great American Novel, and Danzy Senna has set the standard.” –LA Times “Funny, foxy and fleet…The jokes are good, the punches land, the dialogue is tart.” – Dwight Garner, The New York Times A brilliant take on love and ambition, failure and reinvention, and the racial-identity-industrial complex from the bestselling author of Caucasia. Jane has high hopes that her life is about to turn around. After a long, precarious stretch bouncing among sketchy rentals and sublets, she and her family are living in luxury for a year, house-sitting in the hills above Los Angeles. The gig magically coincides with Jane’s sabbatical, giving her the time and space she needs to finish her second novel—a centuries-spanning epic her artist husband, Lenny, dubs her “mulatto War and Peace.” Finally, some semblance of stability and success seems to be within her grasp. But things don’t work out quite as hoped. Desperate for a plan B, like countless writers before her Jane turns her gaze to Hollywood. When she finagles a meeting with Hampton Ford, a hot producer with a major development deal at a streaming network, he seems excited to work with a “real writer,” and together they begin to develop “the Jackie Robinson of biracial comedies.” Things finally seem to be going right for Jane—until they go terribly wrong. Funny, piercing, and page turning, Colored Television is Senna’s most on-the-pulse, ambitious, and rewarding novel yet. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Danzy Senna is the author of four previous works of fiction, including the bestselling Caucasia and, most recently, New People, as well as a memoir. The recipient of numerous awards and honors, she teaches writing at the University of Southern California.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Samba no Pé - First Class
description:
Get ready to feel the rhythm and energy of Rio de Janeiro! Samba no Pé \(Samba in the Foot\) is the captivating solo style of samba danced in the streets and at Carnival, known for its rapid, intricate footwork and infectious hip movements.

You will learn

The Basic Step: You will master the signature quick-quick-slow rhythm that defines Samba no Pé.

Arm & Hip Styling: You will learn how to add the authentic flair, movement, and energy that makes Brazilian samba so captivating.

Technique & Posture: You will receive tips on proper body alignment to help you dance longer, faster, and more safely.

Rhythm & Musicality: You will learn how to connect your movement directly to the irresistible beat of the bateria \(the samba drum section\).

This class is perfect for anyone looking to connect with the vibrant spirit of Brazil, improve coordination, and get a fantastic workout—all while learning the foundational steps of this iconic dance. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Date & Time: Thursdays @6:30PM – 7:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Alibi Bookshop February Book Club: The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store by James McBride
description:
NOTE: THIS IS THE 3RD THURSDAY DUE TO SCHEDULING CONFLICTS  Please join us on Thursday, February 19th at 7pm to discuss “The Heaven and Earth Grocery Store” by James McBride! THE RUNAWAY NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER A NEW YORK TIMES NOTABLE BOOK • A NEW YORK TIMES READERS PICK: 100 BEST BOOKS OF THE 21ST CENTURY WINNER OF THE 2024 LIBRARY OF CONGRESS PRIZE FOR AMERICAN FICTION FROM ONE OF TIME MAGAZINE’S 100 MOST INFLUENTIAL PEOPLE OF 2024 NAMED A BEST BOOK OF THE YEAR BY NPR/FRESH AIR, WASHINGTON POST, THE NEW YORKER, AND TIME MAGAZINE ONE OF BARACK OBAMA’S FAVORITE BOOKS OF 2023 “A murder mystery locked inside a Great American Novel . . . Charming, smart, heart-blistering, and heart-healing.” —Danez Smith, The New York Times Book Review “We all need—we all deserve—this vibrant, love-affirming novel that bounds over any difference that claims to separate us.” —Ron Charles, The Washington Post In 1972, when workers in Pottstown, Pennsylvania, were digging the foundations for a new development, the last thing they expected to find was a skeleton at the bottom of a well. Who the skeleton was and how it got there were two of the long-held secrets kept by the residents of Chicken Hill, the dilapidated neighborhood where immigrant Jews and African Americans lived side by side and shared ambitions and sorrows. Chicken Hill was where Moshe and Chona Ludlow lived when Moshe integrated his theater and where Chona ran the Heaven & Earth Grocery Store. When the state came looking for a deaf boy to institutionalize him, it was Chona and Nate Timblin, the Black janitor at Moshe’s theater and the unofficial leader of the Black community on Chicken Hill, who worked together to keep the boy safe. As these characters’ stories overlap and deepen, it becomes clear how much the people who live on the margins of white, Christian America struggle and what they must do to survive. When the truth is finally revealed about what happened on Chicken Hill and the part the town’s white establishment played in it, McBride shows us that even in dark times, it is love and community—heaven and earth—that sustain us. Books are available in the shop, online and ebooks at bookshop.org/shop/alibibookshop and audio: libro.fm/alibibookshop

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Mama's Broke
description:
Mama’s Broke is a powerful folk duo that deliver a compelling performance with heart and raw energy. Although highly influenced by their Canadian roots, Lisa and Amy are based out of nowhere and everywhere. 

Their two strong voices blend to create haunting harmonies, while they artfully juggle fiddle, banjo, guitar and mandolin, and incorporate traditional dance and foot percussion into their performance. Their original – and often dark – compositions push the boundaries of tradition and the constraints of genre. Drawing from old-time, Quebecois, blues, punk, Celtic, Balkan and  doom metal, they create a soundscape that is both familiar and new. 

Since forming the band in 2014, Mama’s Broke has been gaining momentum fast ; having already completed two European, and several Canadian and U.S. tours. They have performed in a wide range of venues, from circus shows in New Orleans, to pirate ships in Amsterdam, to concert halls in Ireland, to theatres in Brooklyn. In this way, they stay true to the transient nature of folklore, as they travel the world sharing and collecting song.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Forró Dance with Eric and Abigail
description:
Get ready to connect, spin, and glide to the irresistible rhythms of Forró! Originating in the Northeast of Brazil, Forró is a captivating partner dance known for its close embrace, playful steps, and infectious, feel-good music. It is a social dance that will enrich your life, perfect for a night out or a casual gathering.

You Will Learn:

The Basic Step & Close Embrace: You will master the foundational quick-quick-slow rhythm and learn how to comfortably and confidently navigate the essential close-hold connection that defines Forró.

Leading & Following Techniques: Discover the clear, subtle body cues required to effortlessly lead your partner through turns and variations, and how to follow with grace and responsiveness.

Traveling & Stationary Patterns: Learn fundamental steps like the ‘Caminhada’ \(walking step\) and common stationary turns that will allow you to dance on any size floor.

Rhythm & Musicality: Connect your movement to the distinct musical styles of Forró—from the mellow ‘Xote’ to the faster, more energetic ‘Pé-de-Serra.’

This class is perfect for anyone looking to learn a social partner dance, connect with Brazilian culture, and enjoy a vibrant, community atmosphere. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Class Details

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

Date & Time: Thursdays @7:30PM – 8:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

As she prepares chips and eggs for dinner, she ruminates on her life and tells the wall about her husband, her children, her past, and an invitation from a girlfriend to join her on holiday in Greece to search for romance and adventure. Starring Jennifer King *(Bad Dates, Belle of Amherst.)*

Shirley Valentine runs February 6th - 22nd, 2025

Thursday - Saturdays at 7:30pm

Sundays at 2:00pm 

For Tickets Call:

707-484-4874

title: Cheese & Butter Classes
description:
Join award-winning cheesemaker Sheana Davis and wine expert Ben Sessions for unforgettable cheese and butter making classes. Perfect for team building, celebrations, and educational events, our classes are interactive, fun, and easy for everyone. 

From classes on how to make Creme de Ricotta wheel to Mozzarella Pulling to butter-making classes, guests will always leave with a creamy treat to take home \(if it makes it that far!\) – so bring a small cooler with you.  

Food has a remarkable ability to bring people together. 

Cheesemaking classes are perfect for team-building activities, company meetings, team celebrations, staff events, corporate fun, bridal parties, couples classes, girlfriend getaway weekends, LGBT events, EBT education courses, and more. Classes held year-round on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 12:00-2:00 and 3:30-5:30pm. 

See the full schedule of all our cheese and butter making classes here.  

With each class, we give back to the community by providing meals for food-insecure seniors in Sonoma Valley. After learning how to make cheese, our guests can prepare these meals and write personal notes for the seniors on the lids.  

Join us in making a positive impact while having fun and learning a new skill.   

Your Cheesemaking Experience: 



Begin with local wine and an artisanal cheese tasting.

Learn to make cheese and compound butter with everyday ingredients and tools.

Enjoy specialized classes for dishes like lasagna and gourmet grilled cheeses.

Exclusive guest cheesemakers often share their techniques.

Ideal for corporate events, bridal parties, getaways, and more.



Sheana and Ben pride themselves on using ingredients readily available in any local grocery store, with cooking supplies used reside in most home cooks’ kitchens. Guest cheesemakers are often available to showcase their own cheeses and techniques, making the class a truly unique experience. 

Check the schedule for Wine Country-based cheesemaking classes.  

Customize Your Class:To arrange private or corporate classes at venues like Sonoma Fairmont Mission Inn or Silverado Resort, contact us at sheanadavis@gmail.com. We can help create a unique and unforgettable experience for your entire group! Private and corporate classes may be arranged and are hosted at various Wine Country venues, including The Fairmont Sonoma Mission Inn, Silverado Resort, The Lodge in Sonoma, and private homes and estates. 

To register: 

https://theepicureanconnection.com/events/
