title: A Year to Live
location:
Guided meditations, readings, reflections (estimated 5-7 hours/month + monthly Home Groups + daily meditation)

**Access**: Video and audio recording access for 1 year after program ends via our Online Learning Platform

**Q&As**: Monthly, 1-hour, recorded (optional)

Source: North Bay Bohemian
description:
with Vinny Ferraro, Frank Ostaseski and Pam Dunn

This yearlong journey, inspired by Stephen Levine’s *A Year to Live*, is a heartfelt invitation to people of all ages, at any stage of life. Together, in the spirit of community, we will explore how contemplating death can profoundly deepen our experience of living.

In our modern world, where we often shy away from the reality of our mortality, we rarely pause to consider the preciousness of each moment. The Buddha encouraged us to reflect on death not out of fear, but as a way to awaken to the fleeting beauty of our lives. By embracing this practice, we come to appreciate the fragility and impermanence of our existence.

This program is a yearlong exploration of forgiveness, gratitude, and letting go. Through guided meditations, thoughtful inquiry, and intimate group discussions, we will support one another in discovering what death has to teach us about life and vice versa.

**Program Includes**

**Format**: Online via Zoom (must know how to join a specific breakout room manually)

**Teachings**: Monthly (12) large group sessions (attendance at 10 of 12 live sessions required; this must include the first session on Jan 31st)

**Home Groups (required!)**: Monthly (12), 1-hour, self-facilitated, self-hosted Home Groups that meet in between large group sessions. They are a foundational aspect of this program and will be organized by Spirit Rock. Each group will determine a time/day and location (online or in-person) that works for everyone during the January large group session.

**Home practice**: Guided meditations, readings, reflections (estimated 5-7 hours/month + monthly Home Groups + daily meditation)

**Access**: Video and audio recording access for 1 year after program ends via our Online Learning Platform

**Q&As**: Monthly, 1-hour, recorded (optional)

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Salsa Beginner Marin – Saturday
description:
**Ready to learn intermediate steps and technique?** Join on on Saturday – Salsa Beginner Marin

Are you a beginner who’s always wanted to learn salsa? Salsa classes are designed to help you build a strong foundation. In this class, you’ll learn the fundamental footwork, practice the basic turns, and understand the essential body movement that will make you feel confident on the dance floor. This class is perfect for anyone ready to learn the techniques and foundational steps needed to start their salsa journey.

Salsa is fun, and we make learning it stress-free! Our relaxed, beginner-friendly class is the ideal starting point. You don’t need a partner, nor any dance experience!

In this class you will learn:

Basic directional steps that form the foundation of salsa.

Proper frame for comfortable and effective partner-work.

Simple, easy-to-remember turn patterns.

Get ready to learn the fundamentals and have a great time!

**Details:**

**No partner necessary**—rotations ensure everyone dances

Please wear **non-marking shoes** to protect the floor

Arrive 10 minutes early; warm up and settle in

**When:** Saturday, 10:00 am – 11:00 am

**Where:** 4140 Redwood Highway #8, San Rafael, CA

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Marin Arts & Crafts Show
description:
Join us February 27–March 1 at the Marin Spring Arts & Crafts Show and explore over 200 artisan exhibits in a vibrant handcraft marketplace. Inspired by the Arts & Crafts movement, the show celebrates handcraft in all its forms — a wonderful way to welcome the spring season while discovering beautifully made, one-of-a-kind work and supporting today’s makers.

Discover a wide variety of handcrafted goods, including woodwork, textiles, ceramics, jewelry, furniture, artisan foods, and more — all created by the artisans themselves.

Beyond shopping, enjoy live music, hands-on workshops, door prizes, and wine tasting. It’s a lively and inspiring celebration of art and handcraft, perfect for a spring outing in Marin.

📅 February 27–March 1 📍 Marin Center Exhibit Hall 🕒 10 AM – 5 PM daily 🎟️ Free admission & free parking

\#MarinArtsAndCrafts \#MarinEvents \#SpringInMarin \#Handcrafted \#ShopHandmade \#SupportArtisans \#BayAreaEvents

For more details, visit MarinArtsAndCraftsShow.com

Source: Press Democrat

title: Forest Bathing Walk
description:
Come enjoy a gentle, guided Forest Bathing Walk where East meets West at the Sonoma Botanical Garden. This event is inspired by the Japanese practice of shinrin yoku or “forest bathing.” Forest bathing is the intentional practice of slowing down and immersing oneself in the sights, sounds, smells, and sensations of the natural world in order to restore well-being and deepen our relationship with nature.

This walk will be led by Susan Karle, a Certified Forest Therapy Guide, who brings over a decade of experience guiding nature connection practices with people of all ages. Her approach integrates her background in grief and trauma work with a deep respect for the healing power of nature.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Naturally Arising Samādhi and Insight
description:
with Phillip Moffitt

The Naturally Arising method starts meditation practice in a different manner. It begins with a preliminary, preparatory practice in which all the attention is systematically and repeatedly oriented inwardly. During this weekend non-residential retreat, Phillip will teach two practices that create the conditions for what he terms an “inward staying mind” to naturally arise.

The first of these practices is “The Three Renunciations,” which establishes a discerning mind that is free of reactivity and self-judgment. The second practice, the Arriving Sequence, establishes a mind state that is available for practice and aligned with the Dhamma. When combined, the fruition of these practices is a naturally arising responsive mind. In this way, we become free of the efforting that so often plagues our practice.

From there, we turn toward the Four Foundations of Mindfulness and we explore different capacities of consciousness that enhance insight. Throughout the meditation practice periods, there is continual emphasis on directly knowing experience through the felt sense. The result is a mind that has great clarity and is available to the natural emergence of wisdom and compassion.

Source: Press Democrat

Source: Press Democrat

title: Free Rowing Lessons in Classic Rowboats
description:
Have you ever wanted to learn the timeless—and beautiful—art of rowing? The Floathouse crew is here for you! This season, every Saturday from January 17 to March 28, we’ll host free rowing lessons for adults. Register online, and we’ll take you through the basics in some of our stable and beautiful rowing craft: the classic Whitehall rowboat, the classy Adirondack Guideboat, and the cute but sturdy Captain’s Gig.

No experience necessary, and no $$, either. This is our gift to you.

This opportunity is available to all from January though March, 2026. Come once, come every weekend, or just now and then. Make this the year you learn to row, on Petaluma’s Longest Park, the Petaluma River.

Register online, and we’ll see you on the dock!

description:

Registration Encouraged: Go to sonomamg.ucanr.edu Upcoming Events to complete your registration. title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Jazz & Ballet Combo: Ages 8-12
description:
Saturdays, January 17 – March 14, 2026 11:00 AM – 12:00 PM

Experience Level

Beginning

Event Categories: Dance & Movement, Kids

Ages

8 – 12 years old

$200 Total Registration Fee

Registration Fee includes full enrollment for 9 weeks of instruction and the recital costume fee

A fun and positive environment where kids can learn beginning ballet and basic jazz dance steps.

About the Class

A fun and positive environment where kids can learn beginning ballet and basic jazz dance steps. Instruction will include warm up exercises, increased vocabulary and beginning mini ballet barre ballet positions, across the floor exercises, beginning turns and leaps and beginning choreography is taught at the end of class to different styles of music. Exercises will be modified or enhanced to the individual’s level. Class will be conducted in a positive and attentive environment and is designed to develop memorization, flexibility, and musicality. This class will help the student gain coordination and confidence to take into their daily lives. Small performing opportunities based upon a child’s interest but is not mandatory. There will be a recital on Saturday, March 21. More details to follow. Benefits include listening skills and concentration, increased coordination, and an understanding of movement, i.e. time, space, directions and balance, social skills and development of creativity.

Required Supply List

Dance shoes, ballet slippers or barefoot \(Need shoes, see below\) Please no socks \(grippy kind ok\) or just tights as the floor can be slippery. Comfortable clothing to move in or dancewear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off of face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation.

Location

Room 213, Dance Studio

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:
**WHAT:** Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         **Offered Daily:** 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

·         **Experience length:** 2 hours

·         **Wines:** Selections of library, limited single-vineyard, and a barrel tasting of yet-to-be-released Cabernet Sauvignon

description:
For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma. The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. Learn more at  artsguildofsonoma.org .

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description:
Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

title: Annual Chili Bowl Fundraiser for the Sonoma Community Center
description:
Never Heard of Chili Bowl?

Every year, the ceramics department artists begin making bowls in October. By the time they are done, they will have made over 800 bowls, at least 300 cups, and countless vases for table decorations. Local chefs donate delectable chili of various kinds, including vegetarian options.

When you attend a Chili Bowl lunch seating, you will first enter a room with a selection of hundreds of handmade bowls. Don't worry, the bowls are divvied up in advance so that every lunch and dinner seating has a similar selection. Pick your bowl and then head to the kitchen to choose your chili with all of the fixins. We'll have cleaning stations and bags for you to take your bowl home.

What goes into Chili Bowl each year?

900\+ unique handmade ceramic bowls

1 metric ton of clay

40 gallons of hand-mixed glaze

50 kiln loads of bowls, vases, and cups

90 gallons of chili made and served

700\+ people dining throughout the day

Saturday, February 28, 2026 Three seating options available: 11:30 AM, 1:30 PM, and 5 PM

Every February, the annual Chili Bowl celebrates community, food, and clay. Featuring artisan bowls made by the Center's ceramics team and a variety of hot, steaming chili prepared by local chefs, the Chili Bowl brings our community together to create a sense of warmth during the rainy tail-end of winter.

What comes with your ticket?

Lunch tickets \($38 per person\) include a beautiful handmade bowl of your choosing with a hearty chili of your choice, as well as toppings, cornbread, and dessert.

Dinner tickets \($75 per person\) include all of the above \+ a handmade cup and cocktail/mocktail, along with some special entertainment and auction items.

title: Mary Poppins
description:
**The magical, family-friendly musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film.**

***“It’s a roof-raising, toe-tapping, high-flying extravaganza.“* — Joe Dziemianowicz, New York Daily News** 

**The beloved story of *Mary Poppins* soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.**

**Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” this spectacular production will leave audiences of all ages believing that anything is possible—especially with a little magic in the air!**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: Two hours, 50 mins including intermission

Thursdays Adult $33Fri/Sat Eve Adult $44.95; Senior $38.95; Under 18 $31.95Sat/Sun Matinee Adult $55.95; Senior $48.95; Under 18 $31.95Value seating $37.95\*All prices include fees(707) 523-4185**boxoffice@6thstreetplayhouse.com**

title: Unplugged & Uncorked Music Series at Gehricke Tasting Room
description:
Join us for Unplugged & Uncorked, a live music series at Gehricke Tasting Room. Enjoy performances by acclaimed local musicians paired with Gehricke wines, plus Mary’s Pizza Shack available to order. 

Located in Sonoma’s historic firehouse just steps from the square, Gehricke Tasting Room pours small-lot wines made with minimal intervention so you can enjoy the truest representation of each appellation.  

Walk-ins are welcome, and seating is available on a first-come, first-served basis. Reservations are recommended. 

Unplugged & Uncorked runs on Saturdays from 5 to 7:30 p.m.

title: Live Music Saturday Copy
description:
Joyce Grant Joyce Grant singer/songwriter, is no stranger to Vallejo. She performs regularly at the Vallejo Ferry Bldg. Taproom, the Coalshed as well as the Benicia Taphouse. A mezzo-soprano with a voice like dark honey, Grant has been singing jazz and R&B in the Bay Area for over 30 years at venues such the Donatello Hotel in San Francisco, the Ledson Hotel in Sonoma, the Empress Theater in Vallejo, Sam's Chowder House in Half Moon Bay, Nick's in Pacifica to name a few. She is the great-great-niece of famed ragtime composer Scott Joplin and is a frequent participant in the West Coast Ragtime festival. For the past 3 years she has been the lead vocalist for the Walnut Creek Jazz Band, an 18- piece big band. As a songwriter she has released the CD In The Morning \(co-produced with Doug McKeehan , 2010\), a collection of original songs ranging in style from jazz to blues to R&B. She continues to bring her sensitive and powerful vocal interpretations to appreciative audiences that keep coming back for more.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Ron Burris  / An Intimate Evening of Jazz
description:
Ron Burris is a talented saxophonist who is based in Vallejo, California. His early background was in R&B, including performing with Project Soul, a group that later had success as Con-Funk-Shun. After becoming inspired by Gene Ammons, he switched his focus to jazz. A few years ago, Burris released his debut CD, Mr. Cool, soon followed by a second album, Shades Of Jazz, and now presenting his third and latest album, Ron Burris Jazz... Never Felt So Good.

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

- February 21, 2026 \(Saturday 7:00pm\)

- February 22, 2026 \(Sunday 3:00pm\)

- February 28, 2026 \(Saturday 7:00pm\)

- March 1, 2026 \(Sunday 3:00pm\)

- March 7, 2026  \(Saturday 7:00pm\)

- March 8, 2026  \(Sunday 3:00pm\)

title: The Savannah Sipping Society; a Jones Hope Wooten Comedy
description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Steel Magnolias
description:
Set in Truvy’s beauty salon in Chinquapin, Louisiana, Steel Magnolias centers around a group of ladies who frequent the parlor to get their hair done and gossip about anyone and everyone in town – not necessarily in that order. Alternately hilarious and touching, the play is a loving exploration of the profound bond that connects these six wildly different women. This smash hit play became a smash hit movie that audiences loved!

title: Hands on a Hardbody
location: Spreckels Center for the Performing Arts
description:
In this quirky, high-stakes musical based on real events, ten Texans compete to keep one hand on a brand-new truck the longest—and the last one standing wins it. But this is more than just a contest; it’s a hilarious, heartfelt look at resilience, community and what drives us. This soulful, country-rock musical is filled with a moving score and unforgettable characters. Hands on a Hardbody is a ride you’ll want to take!

title: Mary Poppins
description:
**The magical, family-friendly musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film.**

***“It’s a roof-raising, toe-tapping, high-flying extravaganza.“* — Joe Dziemianowicz, New York Daily News** 

**The beloved story of *Mary Poppins* soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.**

**Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” this spectacular production will leave audiences of all ages believing that anything is possible—especially with a little magic in the air!**

Thursdays, Fridays & Saturdays @ 7:30pm, Saturdays and Sundays at 2:00pm Run Time: Two hours, 50 mins including intermission

Thursdays Adult $33Fri/Sat Eve Adult $44.95; Senior $38.95; Under 18 $31.95Sat/Sun Matinee Adult $55.95; Senior $48.95; Under 18 $31.95Value seating $37.95\*All prices include fees(707) 523-4185**boxoffice@6thstreetplayhouse.com**

description:
**A Raven on the Road Production at the Cloverdale Performing Arts Center**

Brimming with humanity and humor, *A Good Deal* is a bittersweet tale of love, loss, and family connections. Developed through the Raven Players’ ScripTease program.

title: Sonoma County Restaurant Week
description:
Come out and Restaurant Week 2026 from February 23 - March 1! This is your chance support the vibrant and diverse culinary scene of Sonoma County and taste the unique flavors that our local restaurants have to offer. By dining out during the week, you'll be supporting small businesses and helping to sustain our local economy.

There are no tickets or passes required. Simply dine out at as many participating restaurants as you would like during Sonoma County Restaurant Week. Each restaurant will have at least one prix fixe menu to choose from.

This year, Restaurant Week is celebrating eateries that feature entrées sourced from 100% Sonoma County sourced ingredients and/or pour Sonoma County wines. Dining farm-to-table has never been so easy!

So gather your friends, family, and foodie companions, and make a reservation at one of our participating restaurants today. Your taste buds will thank you, and you’ll be supporting our local community at the same time. **Let’s make this Restaurant Week one to remember!**

Source: Press Democrat

title: Seed Starting for Spring
description:
Learn the fundamentals of seed starting through hands-on practice in the ashram garden. This workshop covers timing, soil preparation, and early care, supporting healthy growth as the garden awakens from winter. Participants will gain practical skills for starting strong plants at home and deepening their relationship with the spring cycle.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Marin Arts & Crafts Show
description:
Join us **February 27–March 1** at the **Marin Spring Arts & Crafts Show** and explore over 200 artisan exhibits in a vibrant handcraft marketplace. Inspired by the Arts & Crafts movement, the show celebrates handcraft in all its forms — a wonderful way to welcome the spring season while discovering beautifully made, one-of-a-kind work and supporting today’s makers.

Discover a wide variety of handcrafted goods, including woodwork, textiles, ceramics, jewelry, furniture, artisan foods, and more — all created by the artisans themselves.

Beyond shopping, enjoy live music, hands-on workshops, door prizes, and wine tasting. It’s a lively and inspiring celebration of art and handcraft, perfect for a spring outing in Marin.

📅 February 27–March 1 📍 Marin Center Exhibit Hall 🕒 10 AM – 5 PM daily 🎟️ Free admission & free parking

#MarinArtsAndCrafts #MarinEvents #SpringInMarin #Handcrafted #ShopHandmade #SupportArtisans #BayAreaEvents

For more details, visit **MarinArtsAndCraftsShow.com**

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description:
New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Mushroom Hike
description:
Explore the hidden world beneath our feet on this mushroom hike led by local mycologist George Riner. We'll observe their growth, learn to identify different species by key traits, be mesmerized by the display of colors, shapes, textures, and discuss these remarkable organisms' ecological roles, culinary delights, and even a touch of folklore. 

Be prepared for two miles of leisurely walking and chatting over moderate and possibly muddy terrain. Please be aware this is **not a foray**; collection is permitted for this activity through a yearly CA State Parks Scientific Research and Collecting permit. Fungi information is for educational purposes only. Foraging is illegal in CA State Parks.

You must purchase a ticket through this page to attend. Tickets are $10 for general audiences, $5 for students, youth (12-17 years old; children under 18 years old must be accompanied by a parent or guardian), Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf and RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Meet outside the Visitor Center ten minutes prior to the event start time. 

Wear layers and appropriate footwear for muddy/slippery trails, bring at least a quart of water, and if you have them, mushroom identifying guides. We invite you to bring a reusable drink container so your little ones can enjoy hot cocoa after the walk, if desired. Heavy rain cancels; parking fees apply. Parking fees apply.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Naturally Arising Samādhi and Insight
description:
with Phillip Moffitt

The Naturally Arising method starts meditation practice in a different manner. It begins with a preliminary, preparatory practice in which all the attention is systematically and repeatedly oriented inwardly. During this weekend non-residential retreat, Phillip will teach two practices that create the conditions for what he terms an “inward staying mind” to naturally arise.

The first of these practices is “The Three Renunciations,” which establishes a discerning mind that is free of reactivity and self-judgment. The second practice, the Arriving Sequence, establishes a mind state that is available for practice and aligned with the Dhamma. When combined, the fruition of these practices is a naturally arising responsive mind. In this way, we become free of the efforting that so often plagues our practice.

From there, we turn toward the Four Foundations of Mindfulness and we explore different capacities of consciousness that enhance insight. Throughout the meditation practice periods, there is continual emphasis on directly knowing experience through the felt sense. The result is a mind that has great clarity and is available to the natural emergence of wisdom and compassion.

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Unknown Wayne Thiebaud: Passionate Printmaker
description:
Wayne Thiebaud's lushly painted still life's of cakes, pies, and gumball machines are icons of modern American Art. But there is another large body of Thiebaud's art that is relatively unknown: his prints. Thiebaud had a life-long passion for printmaking --- his first print was made of pieces of linoleum he ran through the wringer of his mother's washing machine! And he continued making prints until well into his 90s. This exhibition will highlight Thiebaud's printed artwork spanning 6 decades, exploring common themes and subject matter and the artist's unusual working method. In addition, the exhibition will focus on Thiebaud's extraordinary relationship with his New York gallerist Allan Stone. Stone gave Thiebaud his first major exhibition and continued to represent him for over 45 years, a legendary relationship in the art world. Also join us for a wrap-around program lecture on Thursday, January 29th, 2026 to hear Wayne Thiebaud: The Whole Story from Linda Loveland Reid, an OLLI instructor for Sonoma State and Dominican Universities. In this lecture, we will be discussing Wayne Thieband's versatile and dynamic personality who brough us not only delicious dessert paintings, but also landscapes and figures. In this discussion, we will look at his famous works, review his life, and learn about his extraordinary printmaking skills that are highlighted in the SebArts exhibit. General Admission Tickets are $15.00. Free Public Entry Days Are January 23rd and 24th, and February 21st and 22nd. SebArts Members are granted free entry, and students get $5 off per ticket. Purchase your tickets before the event, or at the door. To schedule a docent led group tour of 6 or more, email RWynne@sebarts.org.

Date and Time: Saturday January 10, 2026 at 10:00 am to Sunday March 8, 2026 at 4:00 pm

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Mobility Class with Efren
description:
This Movement-Fusion class is designed to build foundational mobility, deep flexibility, and graceful flow. It is a unique practice focused on systematically opening the body, enhancing your ability to move with ease, and creating more internal space.

You will leave feeling stronger, lighter, and more profoundly connected to your body’s potential. This class is perfect for athletes, dancers, and anyone looking to significantly improve their overall quality of movement and physical comfort.

About Efren

A health-fitness educator and mentor with over 15 years of experience leading group exercise classes, including aerobics, stretching, strength training, Zumba, and dance workouts. AFAA, NASM, and trained as a Myofascial Release and Precision NMT—TMJ Myofascial Practitioner.

Today, I integrate a holistic approach to movement, blending the principles of mind-body connection.

What to bring: yoga mat, towel and yoga block as well or anything you need to support your practice. We usually do class barefoot. 

Date & Time: EVERY FIRST SUNDAY IN THE MONTH 10 am \(see our schedule for availability\)

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Seed Starting for Spring
description:
Learn the fundamentals of seed starting through hands-on practice in the ashram garden. This workshop covers timing, soil preparation, and early care, supporting healthy growth as the garden awakens from winter. Participants will gain practical skills for starting strong plants at home and deepening their relationship with the spring cycle.

title: Marin Arts & Crafts Show
description:
Join us February 27–March 1 at the Marin Spring Arts & Crafts Show and explore over 200 artisan exhibits in a vibrant handcraft marketplace. Inspired by the Arts & Crafts movement, the show celebrates handcraft in all its forms — a wonderful way to welcome the spring season while discovering beautifully made, one-of-a-kind work and supporting today’s makers.

Discover a wide variety of handcrafted goods, including woodwork, textiles, ceramics, jewelry, furniture, artisan foods, and more — all created by the artisans themselves.

Beyond shopping, enjoy live music, hands-on workshops, door prizes, and wine tasting. It’s a lively and inspiring celebration of art and handcraft, perfect for a spring outing in Marin.

📅 February 27–March 1 📍 Marin Center Exhibit Hall 🕒 10 AM – 5 PM daily 🎟️ Free admission & free parking

\#MarinArtsAndCrafts \#MarinEvents \#SpringInMarin \#Handcrafted \#ShopHandmade \#SupportArtisans \#BayAreaEvents

For more details, visit MarinArtsAndCraftsShow.com

title: Mushroom Hike
description:
Explore the hidden world beneath our feet on this mushroom hike led by local mycologist George Riner. We'll observe their growth, learn to identify different species by key traits, be mesmerized by the display of colors, shapes, textures, and discuss these remarkable organisms' ecological roles, culinary delights, and even a touch of folklore. 

Be prepared for two miles of leisurely walking and chatting over moderate and possibly muddy terrain. Please be aware this is not a foray; collection is permitted for this activity through a yearly CA State Parks Scientific Research and Collecting permit. Fungi information is for educational purposes only. Foraging is illegal in CA State Parks.

You must purchase a ticket through this page to attend. Tickets are $10 for general audiences, $5 for students, youth \(12-17 years old; children under 18 years old must be accompanied by a parent or guardian\), Sugarloaf members, Sugarloaf and RFO volunteers, and free for children under 12. Meet outside the Visitor Center ten minutes prior to the event start time. 

Wear layers and appropriate footwear for muddy/slippery trails, bring at least a quart of water, and if you have them, mushroom identifying guides. We invite you to bring a reusable drink container so your little ones can enjoy hot cocoa after the walk, if desired. Heavy rain cancels; parking fees apply. Parking fees apply.

Source: Press Democrat

title: Naturally Arising Samādhi and Insight
description:
with Phillip Moffitt

The Naturally Arising method starts meditation practice in a different manner. It begins with a preliminary, preparatory practice in which all the attention is systematically and repeatedly oriented inwardly. During this weekend non-residential retreat, Phillip will teach two practices that create the conditions for what he terms an “inward staying mind” to naturally arise.

The first of these practices is “The Three Renunciations,” which establishes a discerning mind that is free of reactivity and self-judgment. The second practice, the Arriving Sequence, establishes a mind state that is available for practice and aligned with the Dhamma. When combined, the fruition of these practices is a naturally arising responsive mind. In this way, we become free of the efforting that so often plagues our practice.

From there, we turn toward the Four Foundations of Mindfulness and we explore different capacities of consciousness that enhance insight. Throughout the meditation practice periods, there is continual emphasis on directly knowing experience through the felt sense. The result is a mind that has great clarity and is available to the natural emergence of wisdom and compassion.

title: Petaluma River High Tide Upstream Paddle
description:
When the tide is high, the Petaluma River opens into a quieter, greener world.

Join The Floathouse crew for a gentle, guided paddle upstream, timed to higher tides that allow access beyond the downtown channel and into a tranquil tidal slough. With extra water beneath us, we’re able to glide into calm, lush stretches of the river that are normally out of reach.

This unhurried paddle highlights the natural beauty of the Petaluma River’s brackish, tidal waterway. Watch for great egrets, blue herons, snowy egrets, turtles basking along the banks, and abundant plant life. The calm water and peaceful surroundings create a deeply grounding experience—many guests say they feel their stress melt away within minutes.

Along the way, knowledgeable guides share stories of the river’s ecology and human history, offering insight into how this upper channel has shaped—and continues to shape—Petaluma. It’s a rare opportunity to experience how close wild nature lives to the heart of downtown.

Beginner-friendly. Sit-on-top kayaks and all gear provided.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

description:

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. title: Arts Guild of Sonoma Presents: For the Love of Art
description:
For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma. The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. Learn more at  artsguildofsonoma.org .

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Maija Peeples-Bright: Life is Just a Bowl of Terriers
description:
Maija Peeples-Bright is one of the few women artists associated with Northern California's Funk Art movement of the late 1960s and '70s. Peeples-Bright's wildly inventive practice comprises robust compositions bustling with animals of all kinds-her "beasties" as she calls them-forming surreal, imaginative landscapes in audacious impasto. Her zoological arrangements represent alternate realities, infusing exuberance and a sense of the absurd into impossible scenarios. Highly distinctive, her textural creature patterns revel in the extreme, often taking up every inch of the canvas, multiplying her beasties into dizzying arrangements. Peeples-Bright invites us into a decadence-gone-wild world all her own. The exhibition will feature a retrospective look at Peeples-Bright's career, from her early days of the Funk Movement to today.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

Source: North Bay Bohemian
description:
In Her Power

A Collaboration by Priscila Soares & JeanCherie

In Her Power is a group exhibition celebrating women’s presence, strength, and creative expression. Anchored by a collaborative, life-size sculptural work by Priscila Soares and JeanCherie, the exhibition brings together works by women artists exploring power as something lived, embodied, and deeply personal.

At the heart of the gallery stands a mountain lioness woman — a guardian figure shaped by two artists working together, each bringing her own voice, materials, and vision. Surrounding this central work, invited artists contribute pieces that reflect their own relationship to power, resilience, intuition, and selfhood.

Rather than offering a single definition, In Her Power invites viewers to witness many expressions of strength — quiet and fierce, ancestral and contemporary, individual and shared. It is both a celebration of women artists and an invitation to step into presence, creativity, and connection.

Opening Reception:

March 1, 12–4pm

Gallery Hours:

Sundays in March, 12–4pm

Location:

Mare Island Art Studios

110 Pintado St.

Vallejo, CA

title: Steel Spines & Sparkling Wines: A History of Women Leading the Charge
description:
**License to Thrill: An Elegant Champagne Luncheon**

Experience a high-stakes afternoon of history and luxury as we celebrate the premiere of **License to Thrill: Lily Bollinger**.

**The Grand Pairing:** Indulge in an **elegant multi-course luncheon** perfectly curated to complement the **award-winning bubbles of Breathless Wines**. As you savor each pairing, author Rebecca Rosenberg reveals the "steel-spined" legacy of the women who redefined the wine world.

**The Legend of Lily Bollinger**

**Wartime Heroine:** Discover how Lily outfoxed the Nazi "Wein Führer" while harboring Resistance fighters in her cellars.

**The 007 Legacy:** Trace her journey from the battlefields of 1940 to her audacious 1970s partnership with **James Bond**.

**The Revolutionaries:** Celebrate the daring legacies of **Veuve Clicquot** and **Madame Pommery** alongside the finale of the *Champagne Widows* series.

**Secure your seat for an afternoon of gourmet dining, award-winning wine, and untold history.**

title: Steel Magnolias
description:
Set in Truvy’s beauty salon in Chinquapin, Louisiana, Steel Magnolias centers around a group of ladies who frequent the parlor to get their hair done and gossip about anyone and everyone in town – not necessarily in that order. Alternately hilarious and touching, the play is a loving exploration of the profound bond that connects these six wildly different women. description:
**Four Southern women turn life’s curve balls into an uproarious, heartwarming journey of friendship, laughter, and fresh starts.**

In this delightful, laugh-a-minute comedy, four unique Southern women, all needing to escape the sameness of their day-to-day routines, are drawn together by Fate—and an impromptu happy hour—and decide it’s high time to reclaim the enthusiasm for life they’ve lost through the years. Over the course of six months, filled with laughter, hilarious misadventures, and the occasional liquid refreshment, these middle-aged women successfully bond and find the confidence to jump start their new lives. Together, they discover lasting friendships and a renewed determination to live in the moment—and most importantly, realize it’s never too late to make new old friends.

title: Mary Poppins
description:
**The magical, family-friendly musical based on the stories of P.L. Travers and the Walt Disney film.**

***“It’s a roof-raising, toe-tapping, high-flying extravaganza.“* — Joe Dziemianowicz, New York Daily News** 

**The beloved story of *Mary Poppins* soars to new heights in this Tony Award-winning musical, inspired by P.L. Travers’ timeless books and the classic Disney film. Set in Edwardian London, the tale follows the Banks family, whose mischievous children, Jane and Michael, have sent every nanny packing—until the mysterious and enchanting Mary Poppins arrives. With a blend of magic, common sense, and a touch of mischief, she transforms their world, teaching them lessons in love, family, and imagination.**

**Filled with show-stopping dance numbers and iconic songs like “A Spoonful of Sugar” and “Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious,” this spectacular production will leave audiences of all ages believing that anything is possible—especially with a little magic in the air!**

title: Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo
description:
Verismo Opera presents Dido and Aeneas by Purcell together with Pagliacci by Leoncavallo

Free Admission. Become a member to support our new free admission policy.  Membership will be good for a year from purchase and will entitle members to early seating \(before non-members\) for performances.

 Stage Directors: Kristin Lund and Jennifer Rineman 

Conductors: Jonathan Khuner and Paul Schrage

Chamber Orchestra with English Supertitles 

In association with Mira Theatre Guild

For company information and to purchase memberships visit www.verismoopera.org

Dido and Aeneas is a monumental English Baroque opera masterpiece.  The story is based on Virgil’s The Aeneid and tells the tale of love and tragedy between Dido, Queen of Carthage, and the Trojan hero Aeneas.  This beloved gem includes stunning choruses, duos, trios and the iconic aria "Dido’s Lament".  In contrast to Dido and Aeneas’ measured passions, Pagliacci is full of uncontrollable passion, jealousy, tragedy, murder, and betrayal.  Laugh and weep with Canio as he sings "Vesti la giubba" \(the clown who cries behind his makeup\).

Mira Theatre Guild, 51 Daniels Avenue, Vallejo, CA 94590

title: Tidepool Volunteer Orientation
description:
This is a two-part training 

The tidepools on the Sonoma Coast State Park beaches are teeming with multitudes of flora and fauna. From virtually invisible colonies of aggregating anemones to sea stars tucked under kelp, there are fragile intertidal creatures everywhere.

Tidepool education volunteers teach school and adult groups how to safely observe and interact with the fascinating life forms of the intertidal zone. Participants learn about the importance of protecting the fragile plants and animals that inhabit this special ecosystem. Tidepool Roving volunteers stationed on beaches during low tides provide park visitors with a safe and educational experience exploring the tidepools. Additionally, docents provide interpretation when our Touch Table is featured at events or along the coast.

No experience necessary! As a new volunteer, you will shadow experienced volunteers until you feel comfortable on your own.

We look forward to seeing you on Monday February 23 for part one of our two-part training

Part 1 of the training: Monday February 23  6 – 8pm on zoom

Part 2 of the training: Field Visit Sunday March 1 from 3 – 5 PM at Campbell Cove, Bodega Head, Sonoma Coast State Park Map to Campbell Cove

title: Overeaters Anonymous (OA) Newcomer Meeting in Santa Rosa
description:
**Is Food a Problem for You? You Are Not Alone.**

Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is a fellowship of people who support each other in recovering from compulsive eating and food behaviors. If you feel you have a problem with food, OA welcomes you—no matter what your background, beliefs, or eating habits.

We hold an in-person newcomer meeting on **Sundays from 4:00 – 5:00 PM** **at Christ Church United Methodist, 1717 Yulupa Ave., Room #4, Santa Rosa**. Contact: Abigail (707) 293-5888. You may view all North Bay OA in-person and online meetings at https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html .

In OA, members experience **spiritual, emotional, and physical recovery** by practicing the **Twelve Steps** and living by their spiritual principles—one day at a time.

OA is **not** a diet club or calorie-counting program.

Members have different plans of eating.

OA does **not** endorse any specific food plan.

If food is causing problems in your life, you don’t have to struggle alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available.

**Visit:** https://www.northbayoa.org/

**Find a meeting:** https://www.northbayoa.org/meetings.html

title: Candlelight Concerts: 90's Unplugged
description: Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Vicious Rumors
description:
American power metallers Vicious Rumors may not be superstars, but the group deserve credit for being true to their musical identity and consistently delivering heartfelt, fashion-resistant music that their fans clearly appreciate. Vicious Rumors were formed in 1980 in Santa Rosa, California, by guitarist Geoff Thorpe. Filling out the original lineup were vocalist Mark Tate, guitarist Jim Cassero, bassist Jeff Barnacle, and drummer Walt Perkins. The band first received recognition that same year when they began performing Metal Mondays in Bill Graham's Old Waldorf night club. These shows represented the birth of what would become known as the Bay Area metal scene: the biggest, longest-lasting, most important metal community in the United States. After self-releasing a few singles and being included on several important metal compilations, Vicious Rumors signed their first record contract in 1984 with the surging Shrapnel Records, operated by fellow northern Californian and metal entertainer Mike Varney. By this time, several drummers had been enlisted to fill a spot vacated by Perkins; Larry Howe got the job full-time and would hold if for ten years. Tate was also replaced with vocalist Gary St. Pierre from Hawaii, Chuck Moomy had replaced Cassero on guitar, and bassist Dave Starr replaced Barnacle. Soldiers of the Night The group's full-length debut, Soldiers of the Night, was released in 1986 to an especially warm European response. East Coast shred guitar hero Vinnie Moore was brought in briefly after Moomy's departure, but the virtuoso didn't stay long, as he was anxious to begin his solo instrumental career. Before the door closed behind Moore, St. Pierre was also sent packing, and the classic Digital Dictator Vicious Rumors lineup was formed: vocalist Carl Albert, guitarists Thorpe and Mark McGee, bassist Starr, and drummer Howe. This group would stay together for nine years. The Shrapnel follow-up, Digital Dictator, was released in 1988, and as the band's popularity began to grow domestically, they were signed to Atlantic Records. The group's self-titled debut for the label followed in 1990, and Vicious Rumors supported it with extensive touring. While never close to a top-level U.S. metal act, it appeared at the dawn of the '90s that the band had a real shot at breaking into the spotlight with bands like Mötley Crüe and Queensrÿche. That upward trend continued with 1991's Welcome to the Ball and 1992's Plug in and Hang on: Live in Tokyo, which commemorated an extremely successful Japanese tour. Word of Mouth During a layoff due to an injury to Thorpe, the group was released from their contract with Atlantic, perhaps due not only to the band's relative inactivity, but also to the declining stateside popularity of the melodic power metal genre. Many European and Japanese record deals followed, as well as a few member changes while the band trudged on through the '90s. Word of Mouth was released in 1994 and the group remained busy touring the U.S. and Europe. As they were preparing their next release, Something Burning, Carl Albert died on April 22, 1995. The band decided to continue on, releasing an Albert tribute EP and live full-length recording of the singer's final performance. Something Burning was finally released in 1996, and the disc featured Thorpe pulling double duty by filling in on lead vocals. This record solidified Vicious Rumors' European base as many positive reviews and another successful tour followed. Cyber-Christ While Thorpe's vocal work was more than competent, the guitarist couldn't approach Albert's dexterity, and a new vocalist was needed in order for the band to incorporate older songs into their live set. Singer Brian O'Connor joined the group for 1998's Cyber-Christ's recording and tour. O'Connor was replaced in 2000 by Morgan Thorn, who appears on the 2001 release Sadistic Symphony. The band went on a short hiatus after the album's release, eventually coming back together in 2006 and releasing their ninth studio long-player, Warball, which saw them returning to the more traditional, less experimental power metal style of their earlier recordings. The band moved to the popular German hard rock label SPV for their next round of releases: 2011's Razorback Killers, 2013's Electric Punishment, and 2016's Concussion Protocol.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

All Levels

Learn the fundamentals of creating handbuilt, functional objects with clay in this 8 week course. Thoughtfully explore the tried and true techniques of ceramic work!

What you’ll do

Deborah Donahower takes you through the fundamentals of working with clay in hand building in this 8 week course. Designed for all levels \(beginners and those more experienced\) Deborah thoughtfully explores the tried and true techniques of ceramic work with her students through structured assignments, allowing her students to develop their own creative voice in the process. This course will emphasize building functional forms with creative surface design in mind; focusing on forms with large areas to explore texture, painterly surface techniques, and much more. Students will receive instruction in hand building, and basic glazing techniques. With your 8 week class registration, students receive the opportunity to purchase a studio pass for ½ off during the duration of their class. title: The Chromatic Voice: Oil Painting Journey
description:
Mondays, January 5 – MAdvance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,arch 9, 2026 9:30 AM – 12:30 PM No class January 19 and February 16

Experience Level

Intermediate and Advanced

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$350 – Registration Cost $35 – Optional Materials Packet

Advance your oil painting skills in a supportive, solvent-free studio while exploring color,light, and challenging subjects to deepen technique and expression.

What you’ll do

This 8-week course is designed for artists ready to deepen their technical skills and personal expression in a calm, supportive, and solvent-free studio. It serves as the natural continuation of the Fall 2025 course “Palette & Possibility,” and is also open to experienced oil painters who wish to advance their practice within a framework focused on cognitive stimulation and emotional well-being. We will move beyond simple objects to tackle subjects that introduce new cognitive challenges, such as atmosphere, reflective surfaces, and simplified portrait elements. Emphasis remains on process over product, nurturing focus, spatial reasoning, and emotional insight. Through an explorative journey into composition, light, and “The Chromatic Voice”—your unique use of color— students will strengthen their artistic voices while continuing to reap the rewards of enhanced mental agility and profound emotional well-being.

Optional Materials Packet & Supply List

$35 includes all necessary paints, mediums, brushes, surfaces \(canvas panels\), and cleaning supplies for the 8 weeks. Students who wish to bring their own materials should view the supply list. You can view the full supply list here.

Membership has its benefits

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Join Our Podcast!
description:
Share your story on Sonoma County Library's Impromptu Podcast! Here are the rules: You will have 30 seconds to read the prompt and then we start recording your story. Tell us your name \(if you want\). Use the prompt in the story. Keep it PG. You have 3 minutes to share your story. When we gather 4 or 5 stories, we will share the podcast on Sonoma County Library's YouTube channel and cable access channel!

title: The Journey: A Painter's Narrative
description:
New Woman and Fox paintings by Teri Sloat celebrate the personal journeys we take as we travel outward through landscape trails or inward through thoughts and dreams. Her ongoing series, Woman and Fox, A Journey, present rich, metaphorical paintings that invite you to pause on your own path and enjoy the distance you have come.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: The Bonsai Show: Bonsai & Blossoms
description:
January 9–March 22, 2026

Step into a wonderland of blooming miniature trees to marvel at the living art of bonsai and the season’s first flowers. Then stroll through our Asian Woodland to admire majestic magnolias, cherries, and camellias in bloom, or join a tour or program to explore this timeless craft.

This year’s all-new presentation by the skilled artisans of the Redwood Empire Bonsai Society \(REBS\) highlights the grace and vitality of flowering bonsai—trees and shrubs trained to bloom in exquisite proportion to their diminutive scale. Delicate plum, azalea, camellia, cherry, and apricot bonsai take center stage, their blossoms appearing just as winter begins to yield to spring. These early bloomers symbolize hope and renewal—reminding us that beauty and resilience can emerge even in the coldest months.

The exhibition also draws inspiration from hanami, the centuries-old Japanese tradition of celebrating the fleeting beauty of blossoms. The Garden invites visitors to participate in this art of flower appreciation through Hanami Strolls—guided walks through the Garden’s Asian woodland where early-blooming magnolias, cherries, and camellias offer their own ephemeral display.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

description:

title: An Abstract Vision
description:
**Exhibition runs April 4 - May 30, 2026**

Deadline for Entries: March 9, 2026

An Abstract Vision celebrates the work of artists creating abstract art.

Abstract art moves beyond representation, with a strong emphasis on shape, color and form. Abstract art has the power to evoke emotions, appeal to our senses and transcend the physical world. Abstract expression captures the delicate, elusive, powerful and radiant energies that fly under the radar of explanation.

We are excited to have you share with us your visions in the abstract and look forward to putting together a dynamic exhibition of work that reflects the power and importance of abstract art.

Accepting the following mediums: painting, printmaking, photographs, sculpture, glass, wood, ceramics, fiber and paper.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience
description:
**WHAT:** Markham Vineyards Private Tasting: The Cabernet Connoisseur’s Experience

**DATE:**            Begins October 1, 2025, Offered Daily

**TIME:** 11am-1pm and 2-4pm

**WHERE:**       Markham Vineyards

                        2812 St Helena Hwy North, St Helena, CA 94574

                        707-963-5292

                        https://markhamvineyards.com/ 

**LINK:**             https://markhamvineyards.com/visit/winery-experiences/

**DETAILS:**

Discover the pinnacle of Markham Cabernet Sauvignon. This privately guided tasting features rare library vintages, limited single-vineyard wines, and an exclusive barrel tasting of The Philanthropist, our flagship 100% Cabernet Sauvignon, expertly paired with local cheeses, charcuterie, and chocolates. A collector’s journey through the past, present, and future of Napa Valley Cabernet.

Each booking is private and guided by a dedicated Ambassador. Guests will also step inside the Markham winery to sample a yet-to-be-released vintage of The Philanthropist Cabernet Sauvignon from a French Oak barrel.

·         **Offered Daily:** 11:00 am – 1:00 pm and 2:00 – 4:00 pm

·         **Experience length:** 2 hours

·         **Wines:** Selections of library, limited single-vineyard, and a barrel tasting of yet-to-be-released Cabernet Sauvignon

·         **Cost:** $150 per Person

·         **Exclusive Member Price:** $95 per Member

**ADMISSION:** Members $95 | Non-members $150

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
A relaxed and elegant garden experience! Your host will guide you through a tasting of our Russian River Valley estate wines. In inclement weather, this experience will be hosted in our charming tasting room.

Enhance your visit with an option to add-on cheese & charcuterie or artisanal chocolates to make your wine country experience even more delightful.

$40 per guest | Refundable with two bottle purchase

Club Member: Four Complimentary Tastings per Visit

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Grape to Glass Experience
description:
Explore the heart and soul of winemaking with our Grape to Glass Tour & Tasting at Dutton Estate Winery. Immerse yourself in the world of wine as you stroll through our chardonnay vineyard, rooted in six generations of farming legacy in the heart of the Russian River Valley. Witness firsthand the art and passion behind our winemaking process with an exclusive tour of our modest crush pad and barrel room. Relish with a tasting of five current releases and a special library wine, accompanied with a curated cheese and charcuterie board, and finished with decadent artisanal chocolates. Note: This tasting experience requires a 48-hour advanced reservation.

$95 per guest | Special Club Member Pricing

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Picnic Lunch and Vineyard Garden Wine Tasting
description:
Begin your wine-tasting experience with a guided tasting led by our host, who will introduce you to our exclusive estate Russian River Valley wines. Once you have found your favorite, choose a glass from our specialty curated wine flight to enjoy with a delicious picnic lunch, prepared by our local partners at Willow Wood Market & Cafe. Reservations required with advanced booking of 48 hours.

$85 per guest | Club Member: $45 per guest

title: Arts Guild of Sonoma Presents: For the Love of Art
description:
For the Love of Art February 5 - March 2, 2026 Arts Guild of Sonoma | 140 East Napa Street, Sonoma Celebrate creativity and Valentine's Day this February with For the Love of Art, a special exhibition at the Arts Guild of Sonoma. The show features Guest Artist Carmela Beckman-Spector, whose intricate pen-and-ink and collage works explore interconnectedness, balance, and quiet beauty, alongside new works by Arts Guild member artists in sculpture, painting, photography, ceramics, jewelry, and more. A free public reception will be held at the gallery Saturday, February 7, from 5:00 to 7:30 PM. Gallery hours: Thursday 1pm - 5pm Friday 1pm - 5pm Saturday/Sunday/Monday 11am - 5pm Admission is free. Learn more at  artsguildofsonoma.org .

Beginning and Intermediate

Event Category: Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$290 – Registration Cost

Explore soft pastel techniques while creating landscapes, still lifes & more. Guided lessons for all skill levels; no experience needed.

What you’ll do

This class will introduce students to basic techniques of using soft pastels as they work alongside the instructor to create landscapes, still lifes, animals and flowers. Learn to layer colors to create luminous, painterly effects. Beginners are guided as they work on the image provided each week; more experienced students may choose to work on an image of their choice. No prior experience is required. Please see the supply list to learn what materials are needed for this class.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

description:

All Levels

Age\(s\)

17\+

$265 – Registration Cost $30 – Materials Fee $295 – Total Registration Cost

Refine your throwing skills in this 8-week intermediate course with Ben! Explore complex demos, surface design, clay bodies & develop your unique style.

What you’ll Create

Develop and improve your throwing skills while exploring a range of forms through multiple class projects in this all-level throwing class.  The instructor guides you through the basic steps of throwing, shaping, and trimming of pottery on the wheel.  This class is a great opportunity for students to hone basic techniques of throwing on the wheel and expand skills in all aspects of pottery.  Surface decoration techniques will be explored. With your 8 week class registration, students receive the opportunity to purchase a studio pass for ½ off during the duration of their class. Sign ups for membership will be included in your preclass email .

Membership has its benefits

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Tap for Kids: Ages 6-10
description:
Mondays, January 26 – March 16, 2026 4:00 PM – 4:45 PM No class Monday, February 16

Recital Date

Saturday, March 21, 2026 Time TBA

Experience Level

Beginning and Intermediate

Event Categories: Dance & Movement, Kids

Ages

6 – 10 years old

$165 Registration Fee

Registration Fee includes full enrollment for 7 weeks of instruction and the recital costume fee

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years!

What you’ll Create

Discover the joy of tap dancing in our Beginner Tap Dance class, designed for children aged 6 to 10 years! This class introduces students to the fundamentals of tap dance while fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a fun and supportive environment. Dancers will learn foundational steps such as shuffles, flaps, and cramp rolls, building towards simple combinations and routines. Through engaging exercises and dynamic music, students will develop timing, musicality, and precision. Perfect for beginners or those with some experience, this class encourages creativity and self-expression while building essential dance skills. Step into the world of tap and let the rhythm move you! No prior experience required—just bring your tap shoes and enthusiasm to dance! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. You can find tap shoes at Discount Dance Supply , Amazon, Capezio, and Bloch and sometimes Target for Kid’s sizes. Any color and style will do. Not necessary for the first class, may wear hard soled shoes.

Location

Room 213, Dance Studio

Step into the rhythm and fun with our Tiny Tappers class, designed especially for young dancers aged 3 to 5 years!

What you’ll Create

Step into the rhythm and fun with our Tiny Tappers class, designed especially for young dancers aged 3 to 5 years! This lively and engaging class introduces the basics of tap dance, fostering rhythm, coordination, and confidence in a joyful environment. Through age-appropriate techniques, rhythmic exercises, and upbeat music, children will learn foundational tap steps like shuffles, toe taps, heel digs and more! Whether your child is a first-time dancer or loves to move to the beat, Tiny Tappers is the perfect way to develop musicality, motor skills, and a love for dance. Tap into the fun and watch your little one shine! No experience is necessary – just bring your tap shoes and a smile! Recital on Saturday, March 21st. More info on recital soon.

Required Supply List

Tap shoes of any color and style, Comfortable clothing to move in or dance-wear such as leotards, skirts, skirted leotards and tights \(with shoes\) of any color or style. Please no tutus or pajamas in class. Hair pulled off face. Dress in layers as it can go from chilly to warm fast! Being dressed and ready for class is part of the experience and encourages focus and participation. title: DIY Bento Cake Decorating Workshop
location:
choosing the right fillings and frostings, mastering the ‘crumb coat,’ and achieving straight smooth edges. From there, the creativity begins! I’ll guide you through delicate pipework, borders, and floral accents to make your cake uniquely yours. ​We’ll celebrate our hard work with tea and a cake tasting, and you’ll head home with your own beautifully decorated 4” bento-style cake – perfect for sharing, gifting, or personal indulgence!

Source: North Bay Bohemian
description:
Schedule

Monday, March 2, 2026 5:30 – 8:30 PM

Location

Room 109, Rotary Kitchen

Experience Level

All Levels

Culinary Arts

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$100 – Registration CostJoin a Quail & Condor instructor for a bento cake workshop! Master piping & smooth edges on a 4” cake. Includes tea & tasting. Take home your art!

About the Class

​The world of cake decorating is vast, but every masterpiece starts with a solid foundation. Join me for a hands-on workshop where you’ll transform simple layers into a beautiful creation. ​We’ll dive deep into the essentials: choosing the right fillings and frostings, mastering the ‘crumb coat,’ and achieving straight smooth edges. From there, the creativity begins! I’ll guide you through delicate pipework, borders, and floral accents to make your cake uniquely yours. ​We’ll celebrate our hard work with tea and a cake tasting, and you’ll head home with your own beautifully decorated 4” bento-style cake – perfect for sharing, gifting, or personal indulgence!

description:
Mondays, January 26 – March 9, 2026 6:00 PM – 7:00 PM Exception: No Class February 16

Experience Level

Beginning

Event Category: Dance & Movement

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$140 – Registration Cost

Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! 

What you’ll Create

Brand new to the town of Sonoma! Join Jasmine for a 6 week series in Beginning Swing & Lindy Hop! If you are brand new dancer or brand new to swing dance, this series is for you! Swing is a fun social dance that is an instantly accessible way to enjoy social dancing to swing jazz, blues and rock and roll music. Swing is a form of social partner dance that evolved from Lindy Hop in the 1940s, and is based in six-count patterns that are simplified forms of Lindy Hop patterns. Enjoy a beautiful community of swing dancers and learn how to social dance. Absolutely no experience or partner needed. Simply show up, and I will provide the dance partner, as most students come alone/single. Just bring comfy shoes to dance in and your own water. Class is for singles and couples, alike! Everyone is welcome. We specialize in brand new dancers! Dance with confidence, build community, and learn something new in a friendly and kind environment! If you cannot make the entire series but still want to join a group class, please email or text Jasmine at \(510\) 388-5498 to inquire how to proceed/register.

Room 110

title: 2026 Seal Watch Volunteer Training
description:
Do you love and want to connect people with the dynamic and beautiful Sonoma Coast? Do you care about the harbor seals at the mouth of the Russian River? Join us as a volunteer for Stewards Seal Watch Program. Volunteers support the safe viewing of harbor seals during weekends in the spring and summer months at Goat Rock State Beach near the mouth of the Russian River. Volunteers can join shifts at Goat Rock Beach, beach near the river mouth, and at an education table at the Jenner boat launch next to the visitor center. With your help, park visitors can learn about harbor seals and their pups, the natural history of the area, and how the Marine Mammal Protection Act ensures their safety.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?* art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?* is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit’s core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU’s Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU’s Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian
